He accepted the glass, cold as ice. The salt bit his chapped lips and the sweet lemon washed in, and he had a sharp, hauling tug in his mind, a small sound like a curtain ring sliding. He looked at Lila’s face and it had gone careful. She placed a plate of banana fritters in front of him and used the back of her wrist to wipe her forehead. A fly alighted and she flicked it away, fierce.

"What did you mean just then," he asked. "Last year…"

"You won," she said simply. "Pie Nusantara. You won it. You wore a garland that made you look like a flower. We ate free for a week because all the bakeries wanted to touch my hand. People asked me for selfies because ‘you’re the cousin of the champion.’ Useless fame, but fame."

The world went slightly soft at the edges, as if he’d stood up too quickly. Arif set the glass back down slowly. The salt rim left a little crown on the wood. "But I—"

"I know," Lila said. "You don’t remember. You remember the race to Pramuka Island, the storm, you remember smacking your head on the bar of the hatch. You remember waking up three days later. You remember me with my hair like a nest and the doctor with his eyes like fried egg. But not… you don’t remember that week. It went from you. That is how it goes sometimes with heads. You knew for a while after—you remembered for a week, maybe two—then it began to slide. I thought it would come back after Ramadan. It didn’t."

Arif swallowed and felt the swallow all the way down. It slotted into a dark corner like a puzzle piece. He waited for the embarrassment to arrive and give him a slap. Instead, something else rose. A little bubble of relief. He had kept the feeling that he was missing important things, and here was one, returned to him with Lila’s flat voice and lemon scent. And yet it was terrible. He could not find the memory itself, only the shape it must have left behind.

"You didn’t tell me," he said.

"You would not have wanted me to pull at it." She raised her chin. "Besides, I told you two months ago. You looked at me like you were watching a show through a wall. I decided I was done pushing."

He let out a long breath. "I am sorry."

"Don’t say that to me like a prayer. We have other things to say." Lila placed both her palms on his hands. Her fingers were sticky with sugar syrup. "Three days to the final. You got the invitation because you’re the defending champion. The organizer also snapped his finger, said ‘the audience love a story with a return,’ the way people like to snap. Are you okay with that? I didn’t want to decide for you. I could have hidden the letter. I didn’t. Maybe I am a bad person."

He snorted. "You are not a bad person." He stared at their hands. "I want to do it. I think—I think there’s a rope attached to it that leads back into the dark. Maybe I can pull."

"Or you can just eat pies and make money. Let me keep my romance narratives for karaoke."

He laughed then, and some tightness loosened. He ate the fritters, and he pretended his heart wasn’t beating quickly. Lila had that effect. She made his problems look like fish that could be netted.

Halfway through his second plate, a man with a comb-over and a shirt printed with tiny anchors approached the stall like a ship sidling. "You are Lila?"

"I am sometimes," Lila said, that friendly-sharp tone she had with customers she did not like yet.

"I’m Satria," the man said. "From Pie Nusantara. The schedule changed. We had a cancellation. Can you come to registration this evening instead of tomorrow?" He pointed at Arif without looking at his face, paperwork heavier in his hand. "Our champ." He winked like he had learned about winking from old films.

Arif did not know whether to be angry that he was being called “our champ” like a pet or amused. "Today?"

"At seven. Mariana Tent. Ancol. Bring your manager."

"Manager?" Arif echoed, glancing at Lila.

"She is the manager, right?" Satria smiled. "We read the blogs. Everybody loves this cousin story. Very heartwarming. You arrive at the pier together, glorious."

"We are not dogs," Lila said mildly.

"I’ll see you there," Satria said, already backing away, body turned half to another stall. "We will give you the new rule sheet. Please don’t be late. Big sponsor involved. We want to make good impression. Many cameras."

"Many cameras," Lila repeated after he left, rolling her eyes. "Bang, I want you to do this for yourself. Not for Satria’s cameras."

"For myself," he said. "Yes." He wasn’t sure if that was true, but it felt right to say out loud. Maybe the truth followed the words like a machine.

The day carried him like a boat caught by current. He went back to the Liris to check on a balky bilge pump and argue about ropes with Paiman, who believed in square knots like they were religion. He tried to lift pieces of memory in the spare minutes—last year, the week of the contest, the crowd. He got flashes that felt borrowed: something bright, confetti, a boy holding a pie like a steering wheel, Lila crying then laughing immediately. He let them come and pass, like unfamiliar fish in a tank.

At five, he changed his shirt, combed his hair with a spoon because he couldn’t find his comb, and met Lila outside the gate. She’d washed her face and put on lipstick that made her look like her mother, who had been a singer on a ferry once, and who now lived in Depok with a man who owned three mahjong sets and a smile like a shutter you couldn’t open.

"Look at you," Lila said. "You look like a nice boy."

"I will ruin it by eating pies like a wild dog."

"You will eat them like a gentleman."

They caught a bus that complained the whole way to Ancol, and watched the city unfold out of the glass. Old neighborhoods with low, tired houses. New towers like spears. A billow of black clouds in the west that promised storm and delivered none. At a red light, a vendor threaded through a line of cars selling tissue boxes, and a small man in a pink helmet passed them on a tiny motorbike carrying a roll of foam as big as a crocodile. Jakarta in all its improbable balance stood around them, and Arif felt a small pride that he belonged to it, even if he belonged like a scar belongs to skin.

"You won last year," he said again, softly, to the window.

"You did," Lila said.

"Nothing comes. Just the feeling of a hundred hands in the air."

"Maybe you only remember the part that mattered."

Ancol was sunset light on water, the air full of popcorn noise and ferris wheel joy. Kids dragged balloons like weak moons. There were tents already up, the Mariana a big white thing with scalloped edges and banners with pies bigger than faces printed on them. Arif saw a blond tourist woman biting into a durian tart and making a face like a cat smelling a lemon. He grinned without meaning to.

Satria met them, his anchor shirt now somehow tighter. He had a clipboard and a radio and the expression of a man everyone would ignore. "Ah! You came. Good." He led them through a side flap, past a row of tables covered in cloth the color of teeth, and pointed to an area with a coffee machine. "Registration first. Then the sponsor will want a word. He has this idea about making the pies… never mind. He talks. You stand there and nod."

"Who is the sponsor?" Lila asked.

"Blue Heron Hospitality. Their new club is near Kota Tua. Exclusive. They want coverage. They are paying for those camera cranes."

Arif felt a little twist. Blue Heron. He had heard that name snapped from someone’s mouth on the quay. A new place, hidden door, quiet men. He tucked the twist away.

They filled out forms that asked him about his allergies and his signature and his shoe size, for no reason he could imagine. A girl with purple hair took Lila’s photo and gave her a laminated badge. "Manager," it read, and below it, "Lila Adidarma," spelled almost right.

"Are we selling lemonade here too?" Lila asked Arif as she examined the badge.

"You could," he said. "There’s always a line of people who want sour."

They followed Satria to a low platform where a man in a linen jacket and loafers waited, his hair careful. He had a smile like he practiced it in the mirror. "Arif," he said. "I’m Gerry. We are very happy to see you back." His English had a California lean to it. "Your story is… compelling. Man of the sea, the return, the amnesia—"

"I didn’t say the word ‘amnesia’ to you," Lila cut in.

Gerry widened his practiced smile. "Everyone knows everything in this city." He brought his palms together with a clap. "I own the Blue Heron. We’re throwing the after-party. I want you to be the first to arrive. Photograph the moment. Our designer made you a jacket."

"A jacket," Arif repeated, flat.

"Gerry loves to dress people," Satria said, lifting his eyes to the ceiling. "Last year he dressed the contestants like pirates. It made sponsors cry."

"Pirates are charming," Gerry protested. "Almost as charming as sailors who can eat pastries like machines. Arif, can we take a photo? Just you and the Blue Heron banner. We’ll just get some… content. We’ll post. People will come. Everybody’s happy."

Arif nodded because he couldn’t see how to say no without making Lila’s life harder. He stood against a blue cloth with a painted white bird on it and tried to look… something. He imagined the taste of lemon again and opened his mouth to mimic what he thought might be confidence. The camera clicked, and then two more times, and then Gerry grabbed his shoulder like a friend. "Wonderful. We love authenticity."

On their way out, Lila touched his arm and pointed. Near the exit flap was a board with photos pinned on, last year’s winners and the year before, with captions. There he was. No question. Mouth smeared with filling, hair messier than now, eyes lit as if someone had switched them on from behind. He wore a garland made of pastry leaves. He was laughing, shoulder to shoulder with a stout woman in a headscarf who had won second. He was somebody in that photo. He was also a stranger.

"Look at you," Lila whispered.

He looked. He remembered nothing from that exact arrangement of atoms, not the angle of the garland on his collarbone, not the shape of the tent behind him. But his chest drew tight in a way that resembled joy. He reached out and his fingertips touched the edge of the photo. It was warm from the tent’s light. He wondered if touching a picture could pull the memory out of the paper like oil from a rope.

"Those are good times," a voice said behind them. Arif turned to find an old woman in an apron, face seamed and eyes bright. "You are the boy. The one who ate all my apple pies." Her chuckle was a rustling sound. "I had to make more. You dropped your trophy and laughed like a donkey."

"I did?" He grinned. "I would never drop a trophy."

"You were shaking with sugar," she said. "We thought you would die and make bad publicity. But you lived."

"What is your name?" Lila asked.

"Bu Dewi. I bake. I baked at my husband for thirty years. He still didn’t rise." She hooted at her own joke. "You will come by tomorrow. I have durian tart. I make it so it doesn’t smell like socks."

"We will come," Lila promised.

By the time they spilled out into the lights of the park, it was full dark, the ferris wheel LEDs cycling through blues that made the water look like metal. Arif’s head hummed. He needed to sit. Instead, Lila tugged at his sleeve. "Before we go," she said, "I have to meet someone. Five minutes." She ducked into a pocket of shadow near a vendor selling ice cream shaped like fish. "I’ll be right back."

"Who, at this hour?" He tried to joke. "Your secret rich boyfriend?"

She put a hand on his chest and pushed. "Don’t be an uncle. Wait. Get me a fish ice cream. The red bean one, not chocolate. I’ll be back before it melts."

He watched her slip into a narrower corridor between tents, where cables lay like snakes. She was steady on her feet, small but strong. He bought two ice creams anyway, hands cold, eyes tracking the space where she had disappeared. He waited through a whistle blown by a man selling balloons, through a song played by a busker with a broken string, through a minute and then five. He bit the tail off one of the fish and let sweet red paste meet his tongue. He checked the time on the dead face of his watch and then remembered it had stopped at three seventeen three weeks ago.

He went round to the back of the tents. The corridor was dim but not empty, workers moving crates, a woman on a phone saying "I don’t know, I don’t know," over and over. He found the spot where he thought Lila had turned and looked. Empty. He called her name and a man shushed him because people were filming nearby. He went farther, glanced behind equipment cases, pushed open a flap that led to a space of ladders and buckets. Nothing. Anger pricked then concern swallowed it.

A cleaner leaned on his broom, watching Arif peer around like a cat. "Bang, you lose something?"

"My cousin. She came through here. Scarf, gray jacket. Pretty, would hit you with her words if you were stupid."

"Many pretty girls with gray jackets," the cleaner said, bored, then frowned, thoughtful. "There was a girl talking to a man in a blue jacket. Like sea blue. Not police, club type. He had a bird on his sleeve. Blue bird." He gestured with his broom. "They went toward the back gate."

He imagined Lila rolling her eyes at a man with a jacket and walking away. But the cleaner’s face made something shrivel. "Blue Heron," Arif said.

"Yes, Bang. New place. Very expensive. My cousin says they make drinks like perfume."

Arif balanced the two melting fish-shaped ice creams and walked toward the back gate. His mouth was dry again in a way that no lemon could touch. The gate led onto a service road with a row of trucks. No sign of Lila. He called her name again and a dog barked somewhere. A shadow moved and vanished. The ice cream began to make a sticky river onto his fingers. He threw one fish away into a bin. He kept the other, superstitious.

He flagged an ojek with a whistle, and the driver, a boy with hair he’d dyed white at the tips, pulled up, cocky. "Where, Bang?"

"Kota Tua. Blue Heron club."

"Sudah malam, Bang. It’s expensive."

"I’m not buying it," Arif snapped, climbed onto the back anyway. "Just drive."

Jakarta at night was a neon river and a patience test. The bike slid through jams and around buses that wheezed exhaust into their faces. Arif pressed his palm against his pocket and felt the letter like a talisman. He had a sudden image of Lila looking unimpressed at an expensive chandelier, of her finger poking a waiter’s chest, of her making a joke the wrong man didn’t think was funny. He shook his head. Lila was not someone who vanished. Lila was a person who filled the air with her opinions and left sugar on your fingers. Fear kept trying to find a chair in him and he refused to let it sit.

Kota Tua had its ghost look on, the old buildings lit up and hollow, like stage sets. Arif told the driver to stop before the square. He paid, including for the boy’s grievance about the hour, and walked along a side street where a man with a hat sold cigarettes from a briefcase. The Blue Heron’s door was not a door. It was a piece of wall a man would ignore if he didn’t know what he was seeing. A very tall doorman stood in front of it, his suit too perfect. A thin blue heron silhouette in metal was set into the cement, no signage. No need.

"Member?" the doorman asked, eyes sliding over Arif’s work-worn clothes with professional disdain.

"My cousin is inside. Lila. She came with a man with a bird on his sleeve."

The doorman barely blinked. "We can check." He had the voice of a man who knew people always had urgent reasons that were not enough. He touched his earpiece, said something, waited for static to answer. "No Lila in our system."

"She would not give her name to your system. She would give you an argument." Anger rose, useful because it gave him a spine. "Let me go inside and look. Two minutes. Less."

"We don’t do that."

"I am not asking for champagne, brother."

"Still no."

Arif set his jaw. He considered, for a hot silly second, punching the doorman. He considered the chalk of the man’s jaw and the weight of his fists. He let the thought pass like a cloud. He took the fish-shaped ice cream from his left hand—the thing you forget you’re holding when everything else is on fire—and pushed it into the doorman’s palm. The man stared at it, genuinely startled. "Please," Arif said. "I don’t have time to make you a story."

A woman’s voice slid in from behind the doorman. "What is this?"

She was all sharp edges and silk, eyeliner making her eyes look like they had been drawn by a calligrapher. She wore a dress the color of tamarind and a smile you could cut bread with. "I like fish," she said, looking at the melting ice cream in the doorman’s hand. "Who are you, sailor?"

"Arif," he said. "My cousin. She’s missing."

"Missing from your sight or missing from the world? Because men love to claim women are missing when they are simply elsewhere."

Arif looked at the line of her mouth and chose his words carefully. "Missing from where she said she would be. She doesn’t do that. A man in a blue jacket took her. Your people wear those jackets."

"They do," she said. "What is your cousin’s name?"

"Lila."

"And your name is Arif," she repeated, as if testing for lies tasted on the tongue. "Are you the pie boy?"

He blinked. "Apparently."

"I watch television on mute," she said. "It keeps my brain company. You look better in person. Come in for five minutes," she told the doorman, who shrugged very slightly like he thought this was foolish but also not his job to challenge. "If you break anything, you pay for it." She took the melting fish from the doorman and licked it once, precise, like a cat. "Delicious. Red bean. Intrepid choice."

Inside, Blue Heron was a different country. Soft light, tables like lagoons, a bar that looked like the inside of a piano. Men in indigo suits and women in dresses that moved like water and smelled like money. A jazz trio unspooled a song that made Arif want to cry for no reason he could say out loud. He scanned faces. A waitress with a tray saw him and frowned at his boots.

The woman in tamarind dress walked slightly ahead. "I am Dara," she said. "I own thirty percent of this place, which means I own the right to regret thirty percent of my decisions. Look left, not right. If you look right, someone will think you want their attention. You do not."

"Have you seen Lila?" he asked.

"I have not. Why would your cousin come here?"

"Maybe to meet someone. Maybe because this place has become the center point on some men’s maps."

Dara’s mouth lifted slightly at a corner. "You read maps?"

"I live in them."

She stopped near the bar and nodded at the bartender. "Send someone to check the private rooms. A woman named Lila. Small, eyes like knives." She turned to Arif. "There is someone you should meet, while we wait. Not because I think you like making friends. Because I am curious."

She led him to a table half in shadow where a man sat with a glass of something golden and a notebook. He looked ordinary until he looked at you, and then he didn’t. His eyes were the color of the water right before it turns into storm. He smiled without showing his teeth. "This is Bram," Dara said. "He sits in corners and makes connections where none exist, which is a talent and a mental illness." She slid into the booth opposite him and left no room for Arif to hesitate. He slid in.

"Bram, the champion who forgot his championship," Dara said. "Arif."

Bram’s gaze snapped a little. "You have stitches behind your ear," he said, like he was noting the weather. "You walk like a man who favors his left knee. What did you lose?"

"A cousin," Arif said. "Lately. And other things before."

"Pie memory," Dara said, accepting a drink that appeared without being ordered. "Your hobby has become community knowledge."

Arif put his hands on the table to keep them from fisting. "Can your man find her or not?"

Bram nodded at Dara. "Private rooms empty."

Dara shrugged, as if to say so much for that. "We checked the cameras outside," she added, a beat later, and Arif tried to decide if she said that to comfort him or to irritate him. "This place watches itself. Nobody matching her description came in."

"Then she never reached this door," Arif said. "Somewhere between the tent and here she went missing." The word felt like it belonged to someone else, but he said it again because it was correct. "Missing."

"You are sure she didn’t decide to take a detour with a man who does not know you exist?" Dara asked.

"Lila likes men who say what they mean and wear un-ironed shirts. This is not her place." He heard the dangerous thread in his voice and gentled it. "Please."

Dara studied him over the rim of her glass. "Men who ask nicely are rare here." She set the glass down. "Bram will help. He owes me, because last year he broke a light with his elbow. Also because I am bored."

Bram smiled slightly, his gaze on Arif’s face. "Tell me everything you noticed," he said. "Start with the moment you last saw her. Every color, every trivial sound. Don’t try to decide what is important. I will decide what is important."

Arif closed his eyes. He smelled lemon still, as if the scent had marked him, or he had been marked with it. He saw the ice cream vendor’s fish and the woman on the phone saying I don’t know and the cleaner chewing his words into thought. He described the man with the blue sleeve with the bird because the cleaner had said it, even though he, Arif, hadn’t seen it with his eyes. He gave them the way the cables lay on the ground. He gave them the laughter of a girl, a laugh that wasn’t Lila’s. He gave them the way the wind had pushed the tent flap open, one-two, like someone calling a dog.

Bram listened like a priest. Dara watched the room with her eyes but her body listened. "Blue jacket with bird," Bram said after a while. "We can find that bird. It is not a common sin."

"You are certain it was the Blue Heron logo?" Dara asked.

"The cleaner told me it was a bird," Arif said. "He called it a blue bird. A heron is a blue bird."

"Many birds are blue," Dara said. "But my men do wear the heron. And some of them are stupid enough to take liberties with it. If a cousin of a champion’s cousin was to be taken, it would not be for ransom. It would be for a message. Or a mistake. Either makes men sloppy."

Arif turned, too quickly, and the whiskey smell whipped at his face. "Taken," he repeated.

"Let us not say the worst thing loud yet," Dara advised. "Let us say lost in the folds of night. For now. Bram, go look at the cameras around the park. Call Rahim. He owes us for the thing with the red scooter. Do it now."

Bram slid out of the booth with no wasted movement, already tapping messages. "He looks like nothing," Dara said, watching him walk. "That is his mask. You need to put on a better mask, Arif."

"I don’t like masks."

"There is your problem."

"One of them," he agreed.

He stood then because sitting had begun to feel like betrayal. "I have to go back to the park. To see for myself. Hang up the sheets in my head and see what sticks to them."

"I will send someone with you," Dara said. "Not to babysit. To help you ask the right kind of questions. Don’t look at me like that. You don’t know which questions are wrong until a wrong person hears them."

"I can handle wrong people."

"Everyone believes that until the wrong person smiles."

He almost smiled back at that because it was painfully true. "Thank you," he said instead. He bowed his head in a way that made his grandmother’s voice rise up in him with a scold about superstition and gratitude. Outside, the city pressed its ear against the wall and listened to him breathe. Inside, a trio played a song that had no patience with fear. Dara watched him with eyes that had paid for a lot of light.

"Before you go," she said softly, "one question."

He waited.

"Do you want to win this thing again?" Her chin tipped slightly toward the direction where the Ancol tents sat, invisible through walls but somehow loud in his head.

He realized his hands had pressed into fists on the table again. He forced the fingers to open. "I do," he said, and he let himself hear what that sounded like. "But not more than I want to find her."

"Good," she said, as if he had answered a riddle correctly. "You are not an idiot, then. That will make your life more complicated and also longer. Go."

He went. The doorman gave him back his red bean fish, now half frozen again by some miracle, because the club was the sort of place where even melting could be paused. Arif looked at it and laughed, short and sharp, and bit into it. He walked back out into the night with his mouth full of sweetness and fear, the letter in his pocket, and the taste of something old at the back of his throat that might have been memory beginning to thaw. He did not run, because running makes men who watch think you are prey. But he moved fast, because not running keeps men who love you stuck in places that make no sense.

He reached the park and went around the back again. The cleaner was gone; a new one had replaced him, a girl with a scarf and a too-big broom who looked fourteen. "Bang?" she said when he asked. "I saw a woman like that. She went into the side tent with a man who talked like a radio." She blinked. "He had a tattoo of a feather behind his ear."

Arif’s hand went to his own scar without his say-so. He felt that silly crescent like a doorbell. He thanked her and slid into the dark between two tents, like slipping between pages of a book. Inside the side tent, he found nothing but ladders and a plastic chair and the ghost of someone’s perfume. He stood very still, let his breath settle, and listened. A fan, moving tired air. The brittle sleep of the city. Distant, the crash of a ride. Closer, a hum of a fridge.

And there, inexplicably small among all the noises, a chime. A phone. One note, then two, then another. It was a ringtone he knew, silly and bell-like, because Lila refused to change it, said it made her feel like her life still had games in it. He turned toward the sound like a plant, careful not to knock anything, and it grew slightly louder to the left. He moved a stack of folded tarpaulins and there, slipped between them like a bright fish, was her phone. Screen cracked, still lighting up a notification. Blue Heron: Your reservation is confirmed. 8:30pm. Private Room A.

He stared at it too long. It chimed again and showed another message, from a number unknown. Bring what you promised. Do not be late.

He did not let himself panic. That would be as useful as shouting at the tide for wetting your shoes. He put Lila’s phone in his pocket and felt it next to the letter, two rectangles warm from his touch. Then he turned and left the tent the way he had come, quiet as he could manage. Outside, the park had thinned but not gone to sleep. The ferris wheel had gone empty and then filled again with teenagers pretending not to be afraid. The smell of fried dough walked by on a man’s tray. Arif breathed once, twice, and went to find Bram with the eyes like storm water and the woman with a laugh like a blade and a club named for a bird that stood in shallow water waiting to spear something.

His mouth tasted like red bean and salt. He thought of the photograph on the board, of himself with pie on his face, and could not find that man in his skin, yet. But he remembered—finally, as if a small stubborn door had opened—a fragment. The sound from the dream, of cheering. And the feel of a ribbon’s raw edge under his thumb.

It was small, but it was something. He clung to it the way a small boat clings to a channel of calm in the strait, knowing the tide can turn hard and early, and prayed to no one that Lila was not further out than he could row.

3

He found Bram before he found Dara, which he decided was luck disguised as efficiency. The man with eyes like storm water had claimed a table near the tent’s perimeter and was making a small nest of receipts and cigarette papers, arranging and rearranging as if the pattern would reveal something if only he respected it enough. When Arif put Lila’s phone on the tabletop, Bram did not reach for it immediately. He looked up at Arif’s face, as if the state of that geography was the more telling artifact.

“She left it,” Arif said, and the ease with which he could tell the truth scared him more than a lie might have. “In the side tent, under tarpaulins. It was on when I found it. It’s got a message.”

Bram slid the phone to him and held it between his fingers like a playing card. He turned it so it lit his own face from below and read. “Reservation confirmed,” he murmured. “Private Room A. Blue Heron. And then—‘Bring what you promised.’” He lifted a brow. “Does she have a habit of promising things to strangers?”

“She promises everything to everyone with a straight face,” Arif said. “And then she keeps the ones worth keeping. For this… she could have promised syrup, lemons, a recipe, a contact. She could have promised to sing a song so badly it breaks glass. I don’t know.”

Dara arrived with a corona of cold air like she had brought the inside of the club with her in her hair. She sat without asking if the seat was taken and took the phone out of Bram’s hand the way a teacher takes chalk. “Our reservation system uses an initial code for all holds,” she said. “We can look up who created this. Private Room A belongs to me. If someone has used it without asking, I will break his wrists and invoice him for the plaster.”

“It does not have to be your place,” Arif began, but Dara was already waving at someone in the shadows and speaking into a small device hidden in her palm, her voice lowering to that silk-threat he had already recognized. Bram half smiled.

“She did not want to be tracked,” Bram said softly. “Your cousin. She left this where it would be found by someone like you and not a man with a flashlight who looks without seeing. She knows where you look.”

“She also knows when to ask me to buy her ice cream like I am her servant,” Arif said, and felt his mouth twist into a shape that wasn’t quite a smile and wasn’t quite anything else. “The cleaner saw a man with a feather tattoo behind his ear.”

“Not my heron,” Dara said, already irritated on behalf of her brand. “We do not allow our staff to be marked like cattle. They prefer to mark their souls with debt.” She touched her ear as if checking for a phantom feather and shook her head. “Rahim has pulled the external cameras for the park. We have a view on the back gate and breakdown lane.”

Bram put the phone back on the table and flattened a receipt beside it. “Before we leave, tell me everything else you have not told me. Quickly. It will save us an hour later and perhaps your cousin a bruise.”

Arif spoke fast, because he could, because he had learned on boats to make your mouth as efficient as your hands when the weather changed suddenly. He gave him the vendor girl with the broom and the radio voice and the fact that the feather sat behind his ear like a secret tucked by a lover. He gave him the cleaner’s boredom built into helpfulness. He spoke Lila’s ringtone into the air and heard Dara make an approving noise, as if an absurd detail was a correct coin placed on the correct counter.

Dara stood, impatient with chairs. “We can do more from a screen than from a table,” she declared. “Come.”

They moved like a small river cutting through a bigger one, making their own channel through the back of the tent, past men in headsets with that grim look of people who make community out of noise, past a mountain of paper plates and a woman who hid a yawn behind a ladle. In a corner where the tent wall folded into itself, a young man hunched over a laptop with cables sprouting from it like vines. He glanced up when Dara’s shadow fell on his keyboard and visibly straightened his spine.

“Back gate, twenty minutes back,” Dara said. “And the vendor paths. And the service road. Give me everything you can pull that won’t feed anyone else’s curiosity before mine.”

The screen offered a black-and-white world before it offered anything else. Arif was briefly furious that the night had been reduced to flat gray and the shapes of people turned to figures without faces. Then one of the figures was unmistakable, head forward, the little seesaw of her arms when she was moving quickly without wanting to run. Lila slipped along the edge of the tent, paused, looked back as if she had left a seasoning behind and needed to remember it. A man came into the frame a second later, jacket dark, with a cut that suggested money and patience. He did not touch her. He gestured with two fingers, like a conductor inviting a quiet instrument in.

“That is one of ours,” Satria said, appearing at Arif’s elbow as if conjured by his own guilt. He had approached on soft feet with a cup of coffee that smelled like it had been waiting too long for a mouth. “The jacket. Owner’s sponsor team gave two to their activation boys. I told them the brand rules, but you know sponsors. They want to be seen without being seen.”

“Names,” Dara said, without turning her head.

“Jonas,” Satria said immediately. “And maybe Tomo. I don’t know the second. Jonas is a contractor. He knows everything about everything but only after it has already happened.”

“Does Jonas have a feather behind his ear?” Bram asked.

Satria had the grace to look like a boy in a classroom who had been asked about the poem he didn’t read. “I don’t look at boys’ ears,” he said weakly, then grimaced when Dara’s mouth simply went thinner. “Maybe he does. He’s with—sometimes he works with Tawa Promotions. They do clubs. They did Blue Heron’s opening party. He has a… tall girlfriend. An actress.”

On the screen, Lila and the man with the expensive patience slipped out of the camera’s view. The feed switched to the service road, where a golf cart with the words “Mariana” stenciled on its side in a script that wanted to be elegant and wasn’t swung into view. The driver wore a cap low. The man in the jacket got in beside him. Lila got in the back like someone who resented the fact of transport. The cart pulled away and out of frame.

“Mariana,” Arif said. “Like the tent.”

“The tent,” Satria said. “The caterer. They run food to the sponsor lounge and move chairs when chairs need moving. That cart is theirs.”

Dara’s phone breathed against her palm. She lifted it and read and for once did not narrate to make a point. “The reservation was made by a code belonging to an external vendor,” she said after a beat. “Somebody who, for tonight, belongs to us and tomorrow belongs to someone else. They put it under a generic name and figured our systems would simply accept the shape of a request because the right letterheads were sniffing around. They were not wrong. Private Room A did not open. But the promise was made by someone who believed it would.”

“Where does Mariana store their chairs when chairs are sleeping?” Bram asked Satria, who blinked and looked like he would rather swallow his radio than answer.

“They have a yard near the northern fence,” Satria said, then tried to qualify it. “It’s where all the vendors put their skeletons. There’s a gate to the service canal.”

Arif tasted lemon again without putting anything in his mouth. “The canal,” he said. “If you wanted to take something or someone away from a maze with two thousand eyes, you would do it where the fishes keep their counsel.”

Dara gave him a look that said perhaps he would have been a poet if he had a different grandmother. “Go,” she said. “Bram, take two of our boys and your brain. Satria, you are not invited. Every time you speak tonight, something foolish leaves your mouth.”

“I—” Satria said, then closed his mouth because for once he had chosen the correct thing to do with it.

They moved again, Bram texting with both hands while walking, Arif pacing him with an itch in the soles of his feet that would not be calmed by any rhythm but forward. Dara’s men materialized out of shadows, as if her will grew staff. One was broad in the chest with a nose that had been broken and reset with evident care, the other narrow and fox-like around the eyes, each of them wearing the kind of shirt that looked like nothing until you tried to pull it off and realized it was expensive. They did not speak to Arif except with their attentive silence, which was fine with him; words sometimes made the ground crumble.

The vendor yard was not a place built for poetry. It was a rectangle of concrete and bad lighting, chain-link fence topped with coils that had known better days and dull knives at their edges. Metal racks held plastic chairs stacked to the height of a small house. Water pooled in the low places and reflected the light in mean little coins. There was a smell of stale oil and something sweeter underneath, like candy left in a car. From the far side of the yard came the chuckle of a small engine and the sound of someone swearing at something that would not fit into something else.

The gate had a padlock that wanted to look fierce. It sat in its hasp like a fat dog. Bram looked at it, looked at Dara’s broad-shouldered man, and the man said, “Give me thirty seconds,” like a promise rather than a guess. He produced something from his back pocket that looked like a hairpin and something else that looked like a secret and the padlock opened with the kind of sigh people make when they realize they have been out-argued. They slipped in, let the gate kiss closed behind them, and divided without needing to agree first.

Arif moved along the edge where the fence met a line of tarps and cases, every sense opening like valves. He saw a piece of scarf snagged on a rough edge of shelf metal, gray, the weave familiar. He did not touch it immediately. He crouched and let his eyes widen and adjust, because he had learned on boats that sometimes the thing you think you see is only the reflection of a thing that isn’t there. Then he reached and took the thread between his fingers, and the itch in his feet moved up, settled behind his eyes.

Beyond the racks, a low building sat with its back turned to the yard. The door was dented near the bottom, where someone had kicked it often for reasons that had nothing to do with cruelty and everything to do with hurry. The air that breathed from the gap between door and frame was colder than the air outside. Bram arrived at Arif’s shoulder and put his palm against the metal. He didn’t push. He listened. There is a way metal talks to you when you know how to ask. He looked at Arif and nodded and then put his weight in the right angle and the door opened.

Inside it was fridges and the thin hum of machines who felt they were performing an important duty. A strip of light jittered at the ceiling from a fluorescent that was considering retirement. Boxes labeled with handwriting sat on the floor. Citrus bar, someone had scrawled, as if afraid they would forget what lemons were. The lettering made Arif’s jaw twitch. He had seen that hand write orders to a delivery guy who always complained about the weight of ice and the cost of gas.

He went to his knees and ran his palm over the tops of the boxes as if he could feel who had carried them. He found one that had tape over tape, a patchwork like a field seen from the air. There was a line of ribbon taped to it, a blue strip with the contest logo quartered across it in white, cut in half by the tear. He touched the edge of it and the movement of his thumb across the raw fabric was the shape of his dream, and his stomach turned. The taste at the back of his throat was not lemon or fear but something bitter he couldn’t name.

Bram took a box cutter from a shelf as if it had always meant to end up in his hand and slit the tape with the kind of care a surgeon gives to skin. He opened the box and found bottles nested like birds, each tucked in newspaper to keep it safe from its neighbors. The caps were plastic but sealed with care. He lifted one out and sniffed it, then offered it to Arif.

Arif did not drink in the way some men did, but he could taste a thing and know its weather. He wetted one finger, touched it to his tongue, and waited. Lemon. Sugar. Salt. Then something too sharp, a high note that did not belong to Lila’s recipe, like laughter in a place where laughter had no business. He frowned and tried again in case the first taste was a lie. It wasn’t. The bitterness was shy but definite, the taste of medicine and a field at noon.

“Quinine,” Bram said, as if reading his mind, and shrugged. “Some bars cheat the bitterness into their drinks. It makes their gins seem more ginful.”

“Lila doesn’t cheat,” Arif said, more sharply than any tonic should earn. “If she wants bitterness she uses peel. If she wants question marks she uses cloves.” He held the bottle up to the jittering light and watched the syrup throw back an oily sheen. “This is not her.”

“Which means someone changed it,” Bram said. “Or someone asked her to make it this way and she rolled her eyes and did it because money makes new recipes.”

Arif ran his thumb along the bottle cap until the plastic bit at his skin. “Or someone took what she made and added something to it because their plan is not our plan.”

Bram smiled with one side of his mouth in a way that suggested it wasn’t a smile as much as acknowledgment of a shape in the fog. “And what plan would that be?”

Arif looked at the ribbon again because he couldn’t not. “Tomorrow there will be a tent full of people with their mouths open,” he said. “An after-party with glasses lifted. Cameras. A sponsor who wants a story. A club that wants to be more famous than it is. If you wanted to lace something through a city, you could do worse than a party where everyone asks for the same drink.”

Bram was nodding when the sharp-faced man by the door lifted his hand, which meant silence and the presence of a thing that made noise even when it wanted to be quiet. Footsteps outside, two pairs, then three. A scrape that could have been a boot against concrete or a box being made to pretend it weighed less than it did. The men moved without speaking, and you could hear when silence had a different owner. The broad man slid toward the door with something heavy behind his back. Bram reached for the light and pulled it off, and the room shrank into the kind of dark that makes you think you have grown new ears.

The door opened a crack and the light from the yard entered like a person. Two shapes came in with it. One spoke in a whisper that wanted to be a shout. “Where are the A’s?” he said. “He told me A’s.”

“Here,” the second shape said, and the whisper had a radio in it. “Here. The tape. A. Put it on the boat. He wants it at Kota before two. Don’t look.”

“Don’t look at what?”

“At anything you will then describe to a police officer.”

Arif felt his heart walk to the end of its leash and stop. He did not move. He breathed. He knew this dance. You made your body become rope, and rope did not exist until it needed to.

The man with the radio moved deeper. You could tell he was sure of his night and the fact that it belonged to him. He bent, his head coming under the stingy light slanting in from the door, and Arif saw, clearly as if someone had drawn it with a good pen, a feather behind his ear. Not a heron’s plume, which would have been too long, but something short, stylized, like a hint rather than a biography. It was inked in dark blue. It looked like a laugh he would not understand.

Bram let his breath out through his teeth and stepped forward out of the dark as if he had decided the time for hiding and stealing things unseen had passed. He lifted his hands to the height of his shoulders, palms empty because sometimes emptiness was a more comforting thing to hand someone than a weapon. “Gentlemen,” he said, in a voice that had the weight of many better rooms behind it. “Wrong shelf.”

The man with the radio turned very slowly, as if he had learned long ago that the way you move when surprised can make a puppet of your fate. His eyes went wide and then flat. His hand dropped to something at his hip. Bram did not flinch. The broad man at the door did what broad men do and made his own shadow bigger than it was by standing exactly so. The fox-eyed man flowed left and became a suggestion near the fridges.

Arif was aware of how warm the bottle in his hand had become and how foolish it was to be holding a bottle when this was the kind of conversation that should be conducted by men holding a different vocabulary. He set the bottle down, because he had not yet made all the mistakes he was going to make tonight and it seemed courteous to leave some for the end.

“We just need to borrow the owner of that phone,” Bram said, nodding toward Lila’s device on the shelf, which was a lie of geography and therefore an interesting new shape. “You take your boxes to your boat. We will take our person to our tent. Everyone goes to bed with their teeth inside their mouths.”

“You are not police,” the radio voice said. He said it as a fact and as a contempt. “Which means you are prey that forgot its place.”

“Prey tastes bad when it’s angry,” Dara said from the doorway, and Arif had never been so pleased in his life to hear a voice that was not his. She stood with her hands in the pockets of her dress like a woman leaning on a balcony looking down at poor choices. She had brought one more man, who had brought a gun but held it like a violin. “The reservation was mine,” she added, not because it mattered but because it was fun to say the truth so hard it made strangers blink.

The feather-ear’s mouth did a small thing and then stopped doing it. “We’re taking the A cases,” he said, because names were anchors and he was trying to steady his boat. “The rest is for the contest. The sponsor pays for after a party. You do not need to know more.”

“I always need to know more,” Dara said dryly. “It’s why I have fewer friends than enemies and better shoes than either.”

Arif stepped forward then because the thing he needed to say would become poison if he held it any longer. “Where is Lila?” He did not dress the word cousin around her name. His voice put that dress on her without trying. “She came with you. You do not leave women outside the door like shoes.”

For the first time, the man looked at him. He looked and then looked at the ribbon, at Arif’s hand, at the place behind Arif’s ear where the thin crescent of scar lived under hair. He grinned briefly and without joy. “Oh,” he said. “The boy who eats pie like a machine. Ferry television. People in my kampung cheered.”

“If you liked the show, you should leave the actor his mouth,” Dara murmured. She had a talent for sounding bored when she wanted to scare someone. “You have one minute to say the name of the place where you left the girl behind, or I will count how many bones your wrist has when it is working and again when it is not.”

“You think he is the kind of man who answers questions because a woman with jewelry asks nicely?” the other man scoffed, which turned out to be his mistake. The broad-shouldered man moved a fraction and the scoffer’s shoulder found the door hard and in the wrong place. He made a noise like someone had taken an elegant idea out of his head and replaced it with a bird.

“Marina C,” the feather-ear said, and he looked like a man who had not meant to say anything yet had found language in his mouth suddenly heavy. “The old fish freezer near the canal. We brought her to talk and she talked like a knife. We left her with the freezer to cool off. The boss will bring her to the club when the time is right. That is not your worry.”

“The time is not right?” Bram said gently. “She will be cold and you will be fired.”

“She’s not alone,” the man said, too quickly now, improvising or sabotaging himself; Arif could not tell which and did not care. “There is a boy watching her. He eats candy like his mother hasn’t taught him how to finish a meal. He has a feather on his neck. He—”

“No more,” Dara said, and the man closed his mouth as if it were a trap closing on the tail of a rat. She nodded once to her men, and they did something with their bodies that did not look like violence until you were paying attention. The men with the radio and the wrong brace of courage found themselves disarmed not of weapons but of their confidence. It was almost elegant.

Arif took one of the A-marked boxes and set it aside, a childish pettiness he did not intend until it was done. The tape bit his palm. He wanted to open every box in the room and pour them into the drain. He wanted to smash every bottle and taste each shard to see if his tongue could pick up lies as quickly as it picked up lemon. He wanted too many things. He took the ribbon instead, the little strip like a blue river cut off from its source, and put it in his pocket with Lila’s phone, and then something in him settled enough to be useful.

“We go now,” he said, but he did not say it like a command; he said it like a boatman at the bow saying the tide had turned and if you did not lift anchor now your anchors would lift you. He looked at Bram, who was nodding, and he looked at Dara, who was already turning away, bored with men on the wrong shelf and interested in men who had built a freezer near a canal out of fish and cement and arithmetic.

The path from the yard to the service canal stank of old ambition. The water lay black and knowing under the low overpass, and a rat paused in the glow of an emergency light to consider them with a seriousness that made Arif want to bow. The freezer building sat like a shrug at the water’s edge. Its windows were either bricked or ignored. A single light burned behind a frosted pane, and the light looked tired of itself. You could hear a generator purr like a cat that had learned to believe its own lies.

Dara’s violin man took the lead. He did not posture with his weapon because only men who are playacting make that sort of theater. He put his back to the wall where the door would open inward and mouthed numbers that made his colleagues’ shoulders shift at the correct syllables. Bram’s voice brushed Arif’s ear, lower than breath. “If you go first, it will be your last first,” he said. “Stay on my shoulder. You will still get to be brave. You can be brave with your mouth, later.”

Arif nodded because he trusted a man who kept his own bones inside his skin. He flexed his fingers once and thought of the way ropes bite when wet and what it means to give a thing a little slack so it does not bite itself harder. He thought of Lila’s wrists with the temporary henna peeling at the edges, that sticky sugar under his fingers. He thought of the boy with candy, the feather like a comma on his neck, and made a quiet, vicious promise to every god he did not believe in that the boy would go home to be scolded about dental bills and not be a dot in a story he could not end.

The door opened as if it had been told to by someone it feared. The smell of cold came out—dry and mean, a winter in a city that had none. Inside, the light made a crop of metal tables look like a field of ice. At the second table closest to the back wall, a figure curled in a chair, her feet bare and one ankle folded too long in a way that told Arif she had been trying to make a rope with her body and had only managed to tire her joints. Lila’s head was bent to one side like she was listening to a secret in the wall. Her hands were bound with something red that looked almost pretty in bad light.

A boy sat on a crate nearby, swinging one leg and reading something on his phone with a concentration that made Arif weirdly proud of youth. He had a paper-wrapped candy between his teeth. The feather ink on his neck was small and absurd and very new, the skin around it still irritated. He glanced up when the door breathed, began to stand, and then did not because Dara’s man had placed a barrel of opinion where it would persuade him to keep his thighs on the crate and his mouth shut.

Bram reached Lila first because Arif felt the floor tilt and he could not find his feet for one hot heartbeat. The rope around her wrists had cut her skin a little. Bram made the knot understand that it no longer had a job. He touched Lila’s cheek with one knuckle and she lifted her head as if someone had pulled a thread from the ceiling and attached it to her hairline. Her eyes were wide and then narrowed because that was her shape when the world came back and needed to be scolded.

“You took your time,” she said. Her voice was rough and made of sand, and it was the most beautiful noise Arif had heard since the first time his grandfather started an engine that had cost a month of prayers. “I am freezing and my right leg is angry and I will never forgive whoever chose that boy as a guard because he pees and does not wash his hands.”

Arif laughed in one breath and almost cried in the next because his body had too many rooms and not enough furniture for all the feelings to sit at once. He went to her and put his hands on her face and then snatched them back because he realized he was standing where men with opinions stood when they thought they owned women. He put them on the back of the chair instead, which felt like a compromise between honor and panic. “You left your phone like a breadcrumb,” he said. “I am a clever bird.”

“I left my phone like a debt,” she said, and then winced when blood returned to her fingers and made it known. “Did you bring me a jacket? No? You are a bad bird.”

“Would you like an apology,” Dara inquired, and it was the closest she had come to gentleness all night. “I only have one, and I am saving it for your cousin when he does something stupid tomorrow on television.”

Lila’s mouth tilted. “I like you,” she said, as if this was a thing she could give and take back like money. “Who are you? No, don’t tell me. Tell me later. Tell me when I am wrapped in something that feels like a dragon.”

Bram cut the rope at her ankles and stood with her hand in the air until he was sure it was a hand and not a feathered wheel about to spin off its axis. The boy on the crate made a small sound like the beginning of a protest and then swallowed it when Dara turned her head and let him see the future he would not enjoy if he made the sound any bigger. He was younger than his tattoo and his arrogance. He was too young for the room he had been put in.

“Water,” Arif said to no one and everyone, and the fox-eyed man produced a bottle that was probably meant for a different problem and which nevertheless solved this one. Lila drank and made a face at the taste and drank again. She looked up at the boy and stuck out her tongue. “I told your boss I don’t keep my recipes in bottles,” she said conversationally. “Men always think women’s work lives inside jars. My recipes live in my head. It is bigger than his jar.”

“You should have just brought what you promised,” the boy said, and Arif heard the radio in his mouth and decided it sat there because someone else’s speech had taken up residence and this boy didn’t yet have enough words of his own to push it out. “Then you could have gone home.”

“I did bring it,” Lila said, and lifted her bound hands as if they were a platter. “You touched it. We all touched it. It was already dirty before you grabbed it. Tell your boss I washed my lemons with holy water and his plan will burn.”

The boy blinked, which was the right kind of confusion to carry home to a boss who liked to think he had vacuumed all superstition out of his men with money. Bram had Lila standing now, gently. Her weight settled into one hip and she drew her shoulders up as if warming herself from the inside.

“Arif,” she said, and he tried not to be the kind of man who goes soft and childish when his name is said in that particular way by a person who has just been returned to him. “He asked for my syrup. A special blend. He wanted the bitter. He said people like premium tastes. He said—” she stopped, thinking, rewinding, like she was lifting lines from a net carefully so none of them cut her palms. “He said if it wins, everybody will want it. He did not think I noticed he changed my bottle for another. So I left my phone and my pride and went to follow the wrong bottle. Then a boy with a feather put me here and told me not to move. He has bad teeth. I told him to floss.”

“You are too brave,” Arif said, and she made a noise that was not a laugh so much as a small storm.

“No,” she said. “I am angry. It is different. Brave makes people monuments before the day is over. Angry gets to eat breakfast.”

Dara made a pleased sound that signaled she had approved a menu. “We will take the A boxes,” she said to Bram. “We will make sure the after-party drinks do not make our guests recite poems at the moon or see God. We will give the sponsor a lesson in what the word ‘ownership’ means. Then we will give the boy with the feather a toothbrush and a job with someone who will make sure he remembers to use it. Then we will crush the gentleman with the radio voice gently between two board meetings until he makes a neat noise. Everyone will learn something tonight.”

“Tomorrow,” Bram said mildly, “there is a contest. Our champion has to earn his photograph again.”

Arif felt all the air in the room turn toward that sentence like grass leaning toward wind. His body, like an engine he had let idle too long, coughed and caught. The ribbon in his pocket scratched his skin where it lay, and the small remembered feel of a ribbon’s edge bookended the sharp newness of rope on wrists and a knot pulled loose. He looked at Lila and said the thing he had not, until this second, been able to afford to say in his own head: “I want to win for the same reason I want to hurt them,” he told her quietly. “To take back a piece of my mouth.”

Lila tilted her chin. Her eyes were still those narrow slits of a person who did not give the night the dignity of being impressed by it. “Then eat their money,” she said. “Eat it in front of everybody. Make them clap for you because they have forgotten what else they came for. Make them pay for forgetting.”

The boy with the candy watched them like he was looking at a species of adults who do not live in his neighborhood. He opened his mouth. “Can I… go?” he asked to no one and everyone, and Dara considered him like a puzzle she might not be bored by.

“You can go home,” she said finally. “You can tell your mother that you tried to watch a woman and she watched you back and you failed. Then you can decide who you want to be next.” She nodded at the door. “Run. Do not join a bigger fish unless you learn how to be a river first.”

He ran, because boys run even when told to walk. He slammed his shoulder into the frame and did not say sorry and did not look back because he had correctly calculated that looking back would make his future worse in the short term. Bram exhaled once and gathered up a box like he had been born lifting weight with calculation. The broad-shouldered man took two. The fox-eyed man did a thing with tape that made it look like it had never been touched.

They left the freezer as if it had decided it did not want them in it anyway. The canal breathed damp and the city farther back was a low shout. Arif helped Lila into the golf cart that had appeared like a magic trick with the Mariana script on it, and for a second the absurdity of the letters made him want to kiss someone for how stupid the world was sometimes and how it nevertheless manufactured grace.

As they bumped along by the water, Lila leaned against him for the first time since they were children and the ferry had jumped a wake and he had reached, unthinking, and made a net with his arms. He felt her ribs and he felt, beneath the ribs, anger cooling to something useful. “You look like you slept on a deck,” she murmured, finding a smile in her mouth despite all its injuries. “You smell like red bean and trouble.”

“They gave your phone a table at Blue Heron,” he said. “Your fame grows.”

“My phone is more interesting than me,” she said, and for the first time all night her laughter came untangled from the fear that had been living in its threads. “Tomorrow, the boy eats pies. Tonight, we go home and I put my feet in a bowl of hot water and swear at the ceiling.”

“And after that?” he asked, because he could not help himself, because this was his fault and not his fault, because he had a talent for making letters into charms.

“After that,” she said, “you find the edge of your ribbon and pull. We see what comes loose. And we make lemonade for three thousand people because Satria promised and I will make him pay for that promise with his pride.”

They were near the tent again, the lights making a field that made strangers into friends for the price of an hour. Dara slid off the cart as if it had been beneath her to sit at all and adjusted her dress like a flag. She looked at Arif and then at Lila. “I do not like saints,” she said. “But I like you. Try not to make me regret it by doing something noble and stupid tomorrow.”

“Tomorrow I will do something hungry and efficient,” Arif said. “Noble and stupid I am saving for next week.”

“Good,” she said. “Bring me a slice of whoever you beat.”

“We don’t slice people,” Lila said, affronted on behalf of the concept. “We slice pies.”

“Same language,” Dara countered, and then she was gone into the light with men drifting behind her like punctuation marks, the night rearranging itself around the absence of her voice.

Bram touched Arif’s arm, and Arif did not pull away because some men’s touch did not move you closer to a cliff. “Three hours of sleep,” he said. “Then we will meet the baker with the laugh who thinks her husband is dough. You will put your mouth to work on something that will not bite back.”

“Bu Dewi,” Arif said, and let the name sit on his tongue like sugar. “Durian tart that smells like socks only in memory.”

“Good,” Bram said. “Always start the day with an enemy you can eat.”

They split at the vendor gate, the men with the boxes going in a direction that would make other men think twice before following, Lila leaning more of her weight into Arif because she had decided he deserved the load by now. The Laut Liris slept at the quay, listening with her tilted mast. The city blinked at them with her hundred eyes and kept her council. Arif felt the ribbon in his pocket and smelled lemon in the creases of Lila’s hair and made a promise to the night, to the water, to the old scar behind his ear, to the piece of himself he could almost remember being attached to a garland made of pastry leaves. He promised to pull until something broke and he kept that promise as both a bowline and a prayer.

Morning came with a bruised yellow light that made the hull ribs glow like old bones, and Arif woke at the exact moment the Liris shifted under him as if she had been waiting to be polite. His tongue carried the ghost of red bean and cold, which would have been pleasant if his jaw didn’t feel like it had been asked to clench for an hour while keeping an oath. He lay for a breath and counted the noises that meant the world had survived the night—the mutter of harbor voices, the rope tender’s cough, the clatter of a bucket on someone’s deck because it had slipped and then been lied about. When he swung his feet down, the floor was cool enough to make his ankle bones complain, and the letter in his pocket found the shape of his thigh without him telling it how. He touched the crease where it was nearly torn and let his breath out through his teeth because there was a day to be had and pretending it wasn’t coming was a luxury people with fewer debts could afford.

Lila had curled herself into the corner bench in the Liris’s tiny galley, a blanket over her shoulders and her hair loose in a way that made her look younger and more dangerous. The rope burns looked like bracelets a child had drawn around her wrists with a broken crayon. She had put a pot of water to heat and fallen asleep with a spoon in her hand as if she had been caught mid-negotiation. Arif stood and watched her for a minute the way a man stands over any treasure you could lose stupidly. He took the spoon gently and set it on the table, and when the water had reached the polite sound of first bubbles, he poured it into a bowl and added salt until it looked like a little sea. He slid the bowl under the table to sit, made tea with whatever leaves had been left in the bottom of the tin, and waited for Lila to wake so he could be smug about having guessed the exact moment her foot would want heat and salt.

“You hover like an aunt,” she said without opening her eyes, which was either evidence of true cousinhood or witchcraft. She pushed the blanket down with her shoulder and the night let go of her in stages, like some old polite animal not ready to leave. “Do not tell me we are late. I will cut time into pieces if it tries that trick.”

“We are on time for nothing,” he said, which made her smile because it was true. He put her foot into the bowl and watched her make the face she made when pleasure surprised her and she resented it. He wanted to say the thing he had chosen to save for light about fear being a stupid dog that ate anything you left on the table, even if it was a phone under a tarp. He wanted to say the thing about not leaving her alone again even if she told him to go play at being a hero and leave management to adults. He said neither, because promises made in kitchens have to be the kind you can keep without a rhythm section behind them.

Pak Kacek appeared on deck like a bad fortune rendered lovingly. He looked in at them through the hatch and shook his head like a rooster who had decided the morning had been arranged improperly. “Your face says you fought ghosts,” he announced, which in his mouth came out as approval. “I brought breakfast. My wife made soto because she thinks soup solves reputations.”

“Your wife is correct,” Lila said, lifting her foot and tapping it dry on the blanket as if she could insult physics into behaving better. “Give it here. I will swallow it without argument.”

They sat with the bowls on the table and ate like people who knew what hunger for anything does when you feed it with the wrong thing. The broth had the exact right trick of heat, and Arif felt it go somewhere useful. Pak Kacek watched them both over his spoon, taking in the sugar-burns, the bruised places, the letter in Arif’s pocket that had worn a map into his clothes. “We will fix the pump at ten,” he declared, because men like him admired schedules almost as much as they ignored them. “Before that we visit the woman who thinks she married yeast. She called at dawn to say her laugh woke two pigeons and a baker and she blamed you for both.”

“Bu Dewi,” Lila said, and licked her spoon with violent neatness. “We said we would go. I’m not cancelling on the only person who thinks a durian should be taught manners.”

They were out into the quay air an hour later, which meant nearly two, because Lila had insisted on changing her scarf three times and Arif had realized he had slept in a shirt that had acquired a fish scale pattern by accident. The city had put on its daytime costume, traffic like a migration done wrong, men and women drawing their days behind them like nets catching half-useful things. A man on the pier had chalked a neat blue feather near the bollards and Arif saw it and let his eyes pass over it as if it were not anything. Later, he told himself, because anger you pick up too early in a day drops under your feet when you least need it.

Bu Dewi’s bakery lived behind a shutter painted with strawberries that had never seen strawberries and under a sign that said “Tart & Manis” in a font that had been excited twenty years ago and had tired since. It had a smell that settled over your head like a hat you would not be embarrassed to be photographed in. She had a flour handprint on her apron in the shape of a country and even more flour in her laugh. She pulled them inside like a tide and made a show of looking at Lila’s wrists and clucking like a hen who knew the value of scolding someone you were going to feed.

“You didn’t die,” she announced. “Very good. I am a selfish woman. If you die, I have nobody to gossip with.”

“I am not gossip,” Lila said with indignation that came out as affection. “I am news.”

“Better,” Bu Dewi said. “News you can eat.” She ran the back of her hand along Arif’s jaw the way aunties test the quality of fruit. “You look like a boy who wrestled a rumor and lost. Sit. I made the durian do as it was told.”

The tart was a miracle of two kinds of obedience. The crust held when it should and submitted when that was wiser. The filling announced itself like a traveler with good stories and one too many shirts in his bag, and yet somehow did not knock any chairs over. Arif took a bite and the exact arrangement of sweetness and something almost rotten but not quite made his nose itch the way strong memory does. For a second the bakery was a white tent and the air was full of breath and ribbon string, and he heard his own laugh from last year, the one Lila had described to him and he had not believed because he did not think he owned that sound. He took another bite and felt the shape of the bite fit into a groove as if his mouth had been saving it.

“You’re there,” Bu Dewi said, as if he had let out a small light from behind his teeth and she had seen it. “You went somewhere and came back with a better face.”

“I remember a corner,” he said, and did not hide his surprise because hiding is for later. “Not everything. But a corner.”

“The corners are where the spiders live,” she said cheerfully. “They make the web strong. It is enough, for now.” She set another tart down, this one apple with thin slices arranged like gills. “If you want your mouth to do its old tricks, you must ask your hands to make the right shapes. Practice.”

“I do not practice eating like a pig,” Lila sniffed, already reaching for a knife. “I practice breathing while watching men eat like pigs, which is more noble.”

“Your nobility can sit,” Bu Dewi said, swatting at the air. “The boy needs water. The boy needs rhythm. I will show you the water. He knows the rhythm already. Even when men forget, their bodies keep at least one song.”

She had never competed, she said, because showing your mouth to a crowd was for people with more stubborn vanity than she could afford. But she had watched three years of contestants and learned what they knew whether or not they wanted to know it. She had arranged pitchers at three temperatures, one with ice swimming like penguins, one at room-warm, and one as hot as a confession. “Men think cold keeps the throat alive,” she said. “This is correct until the cold makes the throat a stone. Then the stone sits and tells you secrets you don’t have time to write down. Try warm. Try hot. See which lies less.”

Arif dunked crust into warm and felt it surrender without turning to paste. Hot lit his chest like shame and made his tongue a stranger. Cold was a promise his hands couldn’t keep for long. He found himself moving in a cadence that was half-work song, half prayer, and realized somewhere under his sternum something had clicked in and said yes, you have done this, badly and then better, and then well enough to put a blue ribbon on your throat and call it a garland. Lila counted under her breath, not numbers but names—“Ayam, ikan, ular,” as if counting animals was less likely to break anything important in the air.

By the third tart he had discovered where to place his breath so it did not insult his swallow. By the fifth he knew the exact point when strawberry glaze becomes an enemy and where to put his eyes so they did not dive into the crowd and drown. He did not remember himself laughing with sugar on his chin last year, but he remembered now how not to hate the feeling of hands clapping because they did not know what else to do when faced with hunger organized into a show. He let himself be grateful for that thin trick of knowing, and when he caught Lila’s gaze sliding over his face with that same carefulness she used to test a syrup, he lifted his chin a fraction to tell her he had found the beat.

“Do not forget to stop before stopping stops you,” Bu Dewi said, and folded his sticky fingers into his palm for him like he was a boy with sugar and a pocket and poor ideas. “People think winning is like a ride at the fair. They do not see the part where it takes your legs away when nobody is looking.”

He sat on the little stool she gave him and let the sugar tremor pass through. Lila poured him tea because she was the only person allowed to pour anything into him without him being allowed to argue. He looked at the scratch on her wrist and watched her flex the hand as if she was telling the skin it owed her a better performance tomorrow. “He wanted my bitter,” she said to the steam because the steam did not react. “The boy with a radio burns for a boss who walks around with a mirror in his pocket and calls it God. They wanted me to help them. They do not know you cannot make a woman like me helpful without paying in a currency I like.”

“You like stories,” Bu Dewi said. “You will take theirs and spend it.”

“I will turn it into a recipe I do not share,” Lila agreed, and blew on her tea with a ferocity that made the steam choose to leave faster.

The front shutter rattled and a head popped under it, trailing a camera and a smell of perfume that had ambitions. A girl with too much energy and too little shame stuck her face into the bakery and said Arif’s name like it was a gossip column. Behind her, a boy with a shoulder rig filmed the strawberries and the sugar and the morning indignation. “Champion,” she sang. “Is it true? Were you kidnapped? Are you saving Jakarta with your mouth? Our subscribers love a narrative with civic responsibilities.”

“We love privacy with knives,” Lila said flatly, which translated into any language as Not Today. The girl made a regretful face that meant she had learned to make regret look like a service. She pointed her microphone at Arif’s mouth anyway, because a mouth is a mouth whether it is chewing or speaking. “We can do footage of you training,” she suggested. “Inspirational. Sweat. Men love seeing men sweat. Women too.”

Arif looked at Bu Dewi, who gave the smallest possible shake of her head, and he decided he had earned the right to receive advice. He smiled at the camera boy the way you smile at someone who is doing a job their mother will never understand. “Today I am training to drink tea without spilling it,” he said. “Tomorrow you can film my sweat and sell it for money. Today is my grandmother’s.”

The girl laughed too loud, because that is how you laugh when you have to sell laughter to an audience that can click away. She was about to push again when a shadow in the doorway made her change her math. Satria leaned against the shutter with an expression that said he had swallowed his pride and it had given him indigestion. He looked at the camera and then at Lila’s face and made the correct decision for once in a day to lower his eyes. “We’re securing the sponsor lounge,” he said without preamble. “And the after-party. There will be no ‘A’ boxes anywhere anyone’s mother can see. I am not a person who enjoys being told I have failed. Please stop being a person who gives me new failures.”

“We did your work for you,” Lila said, and tilted her head so the light caught the ugly neatness of the rope burns. “Send an invoice to your conscience.”

Satria’s shoulders slumped in a way that made him look shorter and younger. “I know,” he admitted. “Gerry is weeping into his jacket because Dara shouted at him until his hair lost its product. I have to stand between men who think the word ‘activation’ can fix everything and a woman who can have me barred from every club north of the old city. If you want to ruin her morning, you will have to get in line behind me.”

“Tell Gerry he cannot put a heron on a boy’s sleeve and expect to remain untangled when the boy decides he is a river,” Bu Dewi said, because she liked to scold men she had not fed. “Also tell him I will bring egg tarts to his party if and only if his people show me their ears before they come in.”

“I will tell him all of that,” Satria said with an expression that suggested he would cut half and add a joke to soften what remained. He looked at Arif then, not quite meeting his eyes. “The schedule is locked. Press conference at noon tomorrow. Finale at dusk the day after. Rehearsal this afternoon for the people who insist on practicing walking onto a stage. If you don’t come, Gerry will send a dragon to fetch you. He has one. She wears tamarind.”

“Tell Dara that if she arrives wearing scales I will fetch my net,” Arif said, and Lila made a sound that might have been a cough and might have been a laugh trying to disguise itself so it wouldn’t be asked to perform.

After the shutter had rattled back down over the girl with the camera and the boy with the shoulder rig and Satria’s headache, after the tarts had stopped announcing their availability, after Bu Dewi had set them to work wrapping pastry leaves in ribbon for reasons that made no sense until she explained a sponsor had paid to have garlands that would fall apart in an aesthetically pleasing manner, Arif stepped into the alley and breathed the particular stink of drains that had been loved and then abandoned. He took the letter out and unfolded it again with the care of a man who suspects his talisman might turn into paper right when he needs it to be a knife. The logo looked different in street light, less jaunty, more tired. He thought of the tiny memory he had plucked from last night like a coin from the harbor bottom—cheering and ribbon edge—and he tried to place it on the paper like a stamp. It didn’t stick. It was not that he remembered more; it was that he was less afraid of not remembering.

A woman with a scarf and a tray balanced on one hand passed, selling plastic bags of palm sugar and gingers. She paused and watched him like you watch a man who has met a river he cannot name. “You are the boy,” she said. “From the board. With the laugh. Last year my niece screamed at the television because she thought you would die.”

“I didn’t,” he said. “I only dropped a thing I was told not to drop.”

“Good,” she said. “Better to drop a thing than a mouth.” She shifted the tray and it flashed with small lights because sugar does that when it is fresh. “You will win again?”

“I want to,” he said, because honesty in alleys costs less than honesty under tents, and the woman nodded like he had paid correct change.

On the walk back to the quay, they passed the chalk feather again and this time Lila crouched and smudged it with her thumb until it was a blue bruise on the concrete. She stood up like she had erased a thing that did not deserve to be a picture. “Let them draw birds,” she said. “We draw boats.” She tapped the letter in his pocket like a bell. “We draw our names on the water and make them float.”

That afternoon, rehearsal was a caravan of people who liked to be important about minor things. A boy with a headset told Arif how to walk three steps and then stop, how to lift his chin as if he had been expecting applause since birth. He showed him where the stage would pretend to be a dock and where the cameras liked faces.
