Lila stood in the wings with a clipboard she had stolen from a girl who did not look old enough to drive and pretended to be unimpressed, which had the immediate and satisfying effect of making five different men try to impress her at once. Arif walked the three steps and stopped and lifted his chin and felt like a puppet whose string had been jerked by a child with sticky fingers. He did it again and made it his. He did it a third time and let himself look up beyond the lights to where the tent met sky, because he had promised himself not to act like a trapped animal even if some men thought that would sell more tickets.

Gerry surfed in and out of the rehearsal with a phone to his ear and a look that said he had decided stress was a brand and he wore it well. When he saw Lila, he went toward her like the letter H drawn by a drunk. He took her wrist in a friendly assault and made a pained sound at the rope burns, which meant he had realized there was a story there he could not tell because Dara would murder him publicly with etiquette. He offered her a jacket from a garment bag that had a bird embroidered on it so large it could have flown away if the stitches had less pride. She took it, because it was rude to refuse a gift in public, and folded it until the bird bent its head as if reconsidering its life choices.

The second-place woman from last year, the stout one with the headscarf and the kind face full of a steel that does not show itself until you bite it, found him backstage and stood beside him as if they had been arranged that way by someone who understood where to place a pillar when your roof was in doubt. “I thought you had become a movie person,” she said, as if confessing to a mistake about the weather. “They said you would not come back because people who win once prefer to be saints and statues. Good. I like beating men who are not statues.”

“You went home last year with a prize and a sugar coma,” he said, and her laugh was the most human sound he’d heard in an hour of camera rehearsal.

“I went home with money,” she said. “I bought my daughter a bicycle and forgave my neighbor for the way he speaks about my lawn. You dropped your trophy and I picked it up because I am a better mother than you are.” She clapped him on the back hard enough to burp a baby. “Your face looks like it has seen something that makes pie sound small. Don’t bring big things to the table. You scare the crust.”

He swallowed a line of gratitude because he wanted to put it somewhere private. He asked her if she remembered a ribbon across his thumb last year and she nodded slowly like a tree nods. “You broke it without meaning to,” she said. “It made the crowd louder. It made you laugh. It made the organizer cry because he had paid for that ribbon and now it was nothing. Do you know how good it is to make a man cry because something is nothing?”

“I am learning,” he said, and when she hugged him, he let himself be the boy in the photo for a second and nothing else.

When the rehearsal broke into parts and fell apart entirely, when the lights went to sleep and the cables sighed, when Satria had been chased by three different clipboard girls about three different clipboards and looked like he would hide in a tent pole if he thought tent poles took pity on men, Arif and Lila walked away from the white scallops and toward the water because it was their habit and because habits you keep at the edge of something wide help your feet remember their job. The ferris wheel lit up and went dark again, a pulse that made people think they were seeing the city breathe. Men rolled cases toward vans. A child tried on his mother’s shoes and clattered like a goat on a tin roof and made two aunties laugh until their eyes leaked.

“Tomorrow,” Lila said, and her voice made that word into the correct size. “Press and pie-tasting with old ladies who think the world is improved by telling boys what to do. After that, a night where we lock my stall and go home at nine like retirees. Then the day. Do you want me on stage with you or in the back making shapes with my face at you until you remember to swallow?”

“In the back,” he said. “If you are on the stage I will look at your mouth when I should be looking at pies. If you are in the back I will look where your face will be and use that as a lighthouse.”

“Good,” she said. “I like lighthouses. I like telling men when to stop. I am good at both.” She kicked a cigarette butt that had been smug near the curb and sent it into a puddle. “Also, Dara sent a message that made my phone feel rich. She says she is borrowing the A boxes to teach a lesson at a meeting that uses long tables. She is going to build a drink that tastes like money without crime in it. She asked for my bitter. I told her she could have my peel but not my rind.”

“Dara with your peel,” he said, picturing it and trying not to smile too obviously at the idea of that dry woman holding a wet lemon. “Bram will tell her where to pour it.”

“Bram will tell her where to stand so she does not get it on her shoes,” Lila said. “He looks like a man who knows where messes begin even when the floor is still clean.”

On the bus home, an old woman climbed aboard with a bucket of small fish and a child with hair braided so tight it could deflect arrows. The smell of the fish knocked the perfume of the city off its perch and made honesty of everything. Lila leaned her head on Arif’s shoulder and when the bus turned, she stayed there. “You were right last night,” she said into his shirt. “About masks. I like Dara because she knows when to wear one and when to make it lift at the corner to show a tooth.”

“I like Bram because he is the kind of man who will pick up a knife when it is needed and then put it down where it belongs,” Arif said, and watched the city blink slowly at them the way you watch a friend fall asleep mid-story.

At the Liris, the harbor night had already begun to erect its horizon of noise and light and rumor. Pak Kacek sat on the stern with a piece of rope and a stubborn knot because he could never sit without making a stand. He watched them approach and nodded at their lives as if he approved of their confusion. “You will win,” he announced to the rope, which meant he was telling it a story about them. “Because it will be simpler if you do. The world is short on simple this week.”

“Nothing is simple,” Arif said, and the older man grinned with all the satisfaction of a teacher telling a student they had finally answered correctly and would now be punished with more questions.

He lay that night with the ribbon under his thumb because he had decided a talisman could be made of anything if you handled it with a particular kind of faith. He listened to the tiny changes in the Liris’s breath and picked out the minute he knew the tide shifted, and he promised himself he would sleep the hours he was owed because if he could not gather himself now he would not be able to hold anything tomorrow. In the quiet that wasn’t quite quiet, he saw the photograph again, the eyes from the board bright as if someone had turned on a light from behind, and he saw a garland of pastry leaves, and he saw a man in a jacket cut like patience signal with two fingers as if inviting a soft instrument to play wrong. He did not see the face he had lost. He decided that was fine. Some men go to war with less and make worse decisions. He would go to a tent. He would go to a table. He would put his mouth where it belonged and take back what names he could.

Morning made him honest about the bruise-blue feather on the quay because someone had chalked another near the warung gate, this time with a neatness that suggested pride. Lila lifted an eyebrow at it and then at him and he shrugged, because if he scowled at every bird he would spend his day hurting his own forehead. He bought two packets of boiled peanuts from a man whose hands had picked fish for twenty years and stressed about nothing else, and they ate standing up in line with other people waiting to be told where to go by small men with whistles and clipboards. The press secretary handed Arif a laminated pass with his name spelled too carefully and a packet of words he was supposed to say when someone gave him a microphone. He put the words in his back pocket and did not intend to use them.

The press conference was a circus that had tired of itself and wanted to go home. Gerry said three things at once and none of them refused to be true. He thanked Blue Heron; he praised Pie Nusantara; he put his hand on Arif’s shoulder and used the word “journey” twice, as if that could cover the distance between a freezer, a canal, and a stage. Dara sat in a chair too far from the microphone to be accused of stealing it and smiled with her eyebrows, which only people who are good at crime can do. Bram lurked in the peripherals as if he had been assigned the job of making sure no feathers entered the building without permission.

A man in the back with a notebook the size of a plank and a chin like he could cut bread with it asked Arif about amnesia and triumph and redemption in the same breath and looked expectant. Arif took the microphone and felt the weight of it and decided to be bored by it instead of afraid. “Last year I ate pies with joy,” he said. “Then a storm ate a piece of my head. This year I will eat pies with the same mouth and a better rope on my heart. If you need a story beyond that, I will introduce you to my cousin. She keeps them in jars, labeled.”

Lila’s laughter cut through the room like a clean instrument and even the men who were being paid to scowl were caught unprepared and smiled at it. Gerry tried to laugh like a bird. Dara didn’t bother pretending. She watched him and when their eyes met she lifted an invisible glass and drank to a joke neither of them had told yet.

Afterward, under the tent flap, a man with ink like seaweed at the side of his neck and a hopeful handshake introduced himself as Jonas, which felt like walking into a room that already knew your name. He wore a jacket that did not belong to him and a cologne that did. His hand was dry and his eyes were the same. “We have some overlap,” he said to Arif in the tone of a man who suspects you have already decided how you feel about him and hopes to undo it with charm. “Tawa Promotions borrowed our boys for the opening. Blue Heron borrowed my mouth for a week. You know how it is.”

“I prefer to borrow boats,” Arif said mildly, and watched the man’s mouth do a small arithmetic and come up at a number he didn’t like.

“I like your story,” Jonas said, because when charm fails, some men try flattery and pray. “Everyone likes a comeback.”

“Everyone likes a man who doesn’t get women tied up in freezers,” Lila said into the space, and when Jonas flinched a fraction, as if someone had pointed a bright light at the wrong end of his day, Dara appeared like a punctuation mark that ends conversations and laid a hand like the idea of wealth on his elbow.

“You’re in the wrong tent,” she told him, and for a second he tried the trick of pretending not to understand her, and then he didn’t, because people who wanted to continue eating at the right tables learned fast. He left the tent as if he had lost something and needed to find it without looking down.

“Will he try again?” Arif asked Dara, and she made a face that said of course he would and of course he wouldn’t, because men often made two decisions at once and then asked the night to choose.

“He will try to be braver with different parts of his body,” she said. “We will teach him to use those parts for walking. In the meantime, Bram has already replaced the A boxes with A-minus boxes and written a love letter to the man who thinks he made a new recipe last night. That man will read the letter tonight in the bathroom of his club and not sleep. Which is my favorite kind of justice.”

They stepped back into the heat and the sugar and the shape of a day the city had decided to bake in a pan a little too small for it. Lila looped her arm through Arif’s and steered him toward the vendors’ alley because she could not help herself; a warung is a compass and she held it in her hands like a ship. “We work until sundown,” she instructed. “We sleep like fishermen. We wake when the harbor clears its throat and pretends to be young. You stretch your mouth and your stubborn. I will make syrups and hide my pride where nobody can break it.”

He made the face he made when he wanted to argue and set it aside the way you set aside a tool you love because the job requires a different one. He followed her, because boats follow the line through chop, because there is a way into everything if you stand at the edge long enough and let your eye soften until the shape appears. He listened to the city crash and purr. He felt the ribbon in his pocket and let his thumb worry it until the edge warmed under his skin. He tasted, in the back of his mouth where some truths stick, cinnamon and citrus and a small, stubborn promise that tomorrow his hands and his jaw would remember long enough for the rest of him to catch up.

The afternoon folded itself into the kind of heat that made even the gulls look like they were conserving adjectives, and the tent people drifted away like a tide that had somewhere better to be. Lila installed herself in the back of her stall like a queen in a corrugated palace and set three pots to simmer at once, each with a different argument of peel and spice. The air filled up with lemon and ginger and the rounder, cuddlier warmth of palm sugar coaxed without mercy, and Arif stood at the edge of the counter with a knife and a bowl and the clear instruction not to bleed into anything they intended to sell. He found a rhythm in zesting because the skin yielded with the same whispering confidence as rope giving under a correct pull, and when he paused to shake the stripings into a tin, he caught himself smiling at the way the smell sat inside his head where worry had been renting a room. Lila counted under her breath while she stirred, not numbers this time but the days of the week backwards, because she said it kept all the other discipline in line, and when a boy tried to steal a fritter off the corner without paying she flicked a wet spoon at him and he laughed with good manners and paid anyway.

Pak Kacek came by pretending to look for a loose washer that had never existed and actually to check whether their faces had begun to look like faces who would survive the next twenty-four hours. He told a story about a Dutchman who mistook tamarind for a charm and wore it around his neck during monsoon and never caught a cold again but also never kept a friend, and then he leaned his elbows on the counter in a way that would have got him a scolding if any of the aunties who truly owned the alley had seen him. He watched Arif’s hands on the knife and nodded once like he was acknowledging a rhythm that had finally remembered itself. When a scooter coughed too close and sprayed a mist of city in their direction, he put his body in front of Lila’s pots like a door shaped like a person, and Lila pretended not to notice because noticing would have made the moment sentimental and then they would have had to make jokes to pay for it.

By the time the sun had climbed over the warung roofs and then thought better of the effort, Dara sent a message that was not a request and not quite a command, and it brought with it the picture in Arif’s head of the Blue Heron’s interior like a second geography. “Meeting,” it said. “Bring your bitter. Leave your pity.” Lila made a face at the phone that would have made a less durable device crack and then decanted one of her syrups into a bottle that used to hold imported olives because repurposing felt like a particular kind of revenge. They rinsed their hands until they smelled like public water and soap instead of sugar and climbed into a taxi because the bus at that hour was a test of patience and they had already passed one exam today.

Inside the club there were fewer people and more light, and the light had been arranged by someone who liked to make money appear cleaner than it was. Dara sat at the end of a long table that looked like it had been made from a single piece of wood cut from a tree that had been asked for an apology and had not given one, and beside her was a small collection of men who had learned to dress expensively in ways that were supposed to make you forget which kampung had given them the first loan. Gerry paced the far side like a dog who had learned a trick and wanted someone to throw him a ball, and Jonas sat two chairs down with his hand around a glass and an expression like a man practicing contrition in a mirror. Bram stood by the window looking at the harbor as if it had whispered something rude and he was considering whether to laugh.

Dara placed one of the A-marked bottles on the table with a neatness that suggested a ceremony, and then she placed Lila’s bottle beside it like a judge putting down two versions of the truth. She did not speak immediately, and the silence made the men’s watches suddenly very loud. When she did finally use her mouth, she did it very gently, which made every sentence sound like an insult you would thank her for. She explained, crisp as paper edges, how private rooms have codes and codes leave footprints, how sponsors who desire discretion often confuse it with impunity, and how bitter is not an ingredient you purchase from a man with a radio and a logo; it is an agreement between tongue and throat and memory. She unscrewed the A bottle first and handed it to Gerry without looking at his face, then to Jonas, and then to a man with a square ring who had been pretending to be a piece of furniture. They sipped and made the faces men make when they do not want to admit they taste a mistake.

Lila said nothing until the very end of the tasting circle. She tipped a capful of her own syrup against her wrist and inhaled and then did the same with the A bottle, and something in her shoulders changed like a sail that had found its true wind. “You’re trying to make expensive taste like medicine,” she said quietly, directing the sentence not to Gerry because he would have made it into a lifestyle, but to Jonas because his eyes had flinched when he tasted the wrong bitter. “You’re trying to teach a crowd to believe that a punishment is sophistication. That trick works until the second glass and then it ends with someone crying into a cab and telling the story wrong to a friend who will put it on the internet.”

Jonas tried to smile with complicity and found he had no spare muscles for it. Gerry glanced at Dara and performed a sigh as if he had been expecting to be disappointed all his life and was relieved to finally have the chance. Dara cut a small slice of the air with two fingers and everyone’s gaze followed it like a flock. “We will not serve your tonic,” she said. “We will serve something that makes people want to spend money because they are happy and not because they have been tricked into mistaking numbness for taste. If you insist on putting your logo on a bottle of quinine with delusions, you may do so in your own room for your own friends. If you insist on bringing boys with feathers behind their ears into my gardens, I will put seeds in their pockets they do not want.”

The man with the ring began to protest in the language of legal men and long tables and contracts that believe they have souls, and Bram leaned off the window and into the room just enough to change the gravity. He did not threaten; he enumerated. He listed how many cameras had seen which cart and where the ribbon had been torn. He sketched, without naming, the video of Jonas with his hand on a handle that had been meant for chairs and not for people. He mentioned the boy with the candy and the freezer with the tired light. He asked whether anyone in the room wished to sublicense the kinds of stories that come blowing in off canals when the wind changes. By the time he finished, the man with the ring was polishing the square as if it had begun to feel tight.

What made the meeting end was not Dara’s ice or Bram’s arithmetic, though either would have done; it was Lila sliding her bottle toward the center with two fingers and saying, without any drama, “Use this or don’t. But don’t use me without paying me and thinking I won’t notice.” The sentence hung in the air like a banner at a parade, and even the air condicioning decided to hum less loudly for a moment. Gerry’s smile tried on an expression that looked like sincerity and kept it because it fit better than he expected, and he nodded, and the kind of paperwork that births better nights began to unroll in the minds of men who had come ready to roll something else.

On the way out, Jonas drifted near with the intention of practicing contrition aloud, but Dara blocked him with a palm lifted like a traffic cop who has a manicure. She told him, without heat, that he had chosen the wrong kind of clever and he needed to choose the other kind before his luck bored itself. He swallowed and looked at Arif as if asking for a version of forgiveness he might somehow deserve, and Arif gave him the kind that has no words and is not forgiveness at all, just the decision to save his mouth for pies and not for men who had been warned.

They came back into the heat like swimmers who had misjudged the edge of a pool and were resigned to climbing instead of floating. Bram walked beside Arif with his hands in his pockets, which made him look like a person with less to do than he actually had. The street was a slow river of the stubborn and the tired and the genuinely happy, and somewhere close by a woman sold cut guava with salt that made its own weather in your mouth. “Feathers are a cheap symbol,” Bram said after a block, not looking at him and yet speaking to the exact part of Arif that needed speaking to. “Pretty, easy to draw, suggests flight and grace but also an ache, because what is a feather without a body. People love ache. They forget depth.”

“Who is his body,” Arif asked, because men like Jonas do not buy fifty cheap tattoos without admiring a bird that thinks it is a river. “Who lifts his wings when the money is heavy.”

“Someone with a name that doesn’t belong in a mouth that earns its own money,” Bram said, and his tone was not bored so much as clinical. “A man you’ve seen at docks and offices and tables where women are asked to laugh. He will not approach you yet because you are a story he hasn’t decided the ending of. He will send boys with more nerve than sense. He will experiment with how much lemon it takes to cover a taste people shouldn’t be swallowing.”

Arif let that settle like a coin at the bottom of a glass. He did not love the idea of becoming anyone’s experiment again, even in metaphor, and he was surprised at the small joy that accompanied the thought of being boring to the kind of men who made fevers into business models. “Then we bore him,” he said. “We win the contest, we drink gentle drinks, we sleep, and he finds another bird to pluck.”

Bram smiled with one corner of his mouth because he appreciated hope when it dressed itself in work clothes. “And while he looks away,” he said, “we cut the string on his kite.”

The evening let them go slowly, like a hand hanging on to yours a breath too long and then choosing not to insult you by pretending it had simply forgotten to unclasp. Back at the quay the light had the drowsy tilt of a man who wants to tell another story and cannot decide between a lie and a miracle; the Liris rocked with the particular patience of things built to endure time instead of attention. Lila, who had declared herself unwilling to make any more syrup until the morning ruined itself, produced a pot of rice, a wok that looked like it had participated in six family histories, and a small hill of leftover fried fish that she attacked with a fork until it became something a person could call a new dish without guilt. Arif cleaned two cucumbers with the quick strokes of someone who had learned, young, that water tastes like various truths depending on what you put next to it, and they ate on the stern under a sky that consented to be dramatic without going to the trouble of becoming storm.

Somewhere between second helping and the kind of soft quiet that comes only after the kitchen no longer needs you, the ribbon in Arif’s pocket stopped being just an edge against his thigh and turned into a small bright nerve under his thumb, and he closed his eyes without meaning to. He could feel, for half of one breath, the exact moment last year when the crowd had become large enough that it had its own heartbeat, and he could hear the cheer tilt like a wave and almost break on the sound of cloth tearing when his thumb caught the riband, and his mouth remembered making a joke that made no sense and made perfect sense because his blood had been ninety percent sugar and the rest adrenaline. It was not a whole memory, and it did not deliver the face he had worn that day back to him like a gift, but it left a wet footprint where there had been none, and he cherished it as a man cherishes signs that his boat hasn’t forgotten the channel yet.

He slept then like a person who had been given permission by a boat and woke with that permission intact. Morning tried out the idea of rain and decided against it, which meant the air was wet anyway and everyone had an extra complaint to carry around. The schedule was a ladder: a vendor round at nine because Lila had arranged swaps with two aunties who had tamarind she coveted and couldn’t be bothered to buy, another rehearsal at eleven that nobody needed and everyone would attend because rehearsal rooms are where gossip is free, and a phrase called “security walkthrough” at three that made Arif itch. He watched the quay breathe and spotted, with an uncharitable satisfaction, that the chalk feather had been trampled by a wheelbarrow and then spat on by a man who hated the way the color blue sometimes thought it owned the sky.

It was Lila who saw the boy first, because her eyes loved intent like a cat loves a half-closed door. He loitered near the stall with the stance of a child who has been told to loiter without getting slapped by an aunt he doesn’t know, and his hand sat in his pocket like it had been tied there. He waited until what he thought would be the perfect unsuspecting moment and moved toward Lila’s prep bench with an insouciance that could have been admirable if it hadn’t been so obvious, and her hand clamped his wrist so fast his whole arm told him truths. The vial he had been carrying went cold and brittle between their fingers, and she lifted it gently as if it were a small glass opinion that might shatter if mishandled.

“Inside voice,” she said to him, and then to Arif, “Open that with your nose, not your hands.” The boy stared at the ground and at the vial and at Lila’s braid like he had only just noticed hair was a thing people owned; he couldn’t have been more than fourteen and he had done very badly at choosing which adults to believe this week. Arif flicked the cap and brought the mouth of the little bottle near without letting it touch skin, and a whiff of something tidy and unfriendly wrote itself in the front of his head. It was a polite cousin of what they had tasted in the A bottle and a poor liar, and it would have made an honest drink taste like a debt.

“Who?” Lila asked, not unkindly and not gently, and the boy made the small fish mouth that belongs to children who have been bribed by men who do not keep promises. He told them a name he didn’t know how to spell and the location of a gaming shop near Kota Tua where tall men laughed too hard at their own jokes. He held his other wrist with his free hand like the limb warranted sympathy for being caught and confessed, in a rush, that he had been promised a pair of shoes that make YouTube boys tall if he would pour this where told and then leave it because he was stupid and the shoes were beautiful and his mother’s back hurt and the world told him stories in which handsome men are forgiving.

Pak Kacek had watched the entire exchange with the calm of a storm that hasn’t decided which village to pick up yet. He stepped closer now and the boy flinched out of habit, then relaxed when he realized this was not a man who hit children in front of other people. “You will take those shoes,” Pak decreed, which earned him a scandalized look from both Lila and Arif that pleased him very much. “You will take them, you will sell them to a person who collects ugly things and does not run, and you will bring your mother a bag of rice and a duck. Then you will come to me on Tuesday and learn to tie a knot I can trust. If you don’t arrive, I will assume you tripped on your own lie and drowned and I will send a ghost to your house who eats only shoes.”

The boy nodded with the awe that belongs to threats that include poultry and supernatural consequences, and Lila handed him a parcel of fritters and a bottle of proper lemon syrup and told him this was the kind of sweetness that did not ask his mouth to forget its manners. The vial went into Bram’s pocket later with the look of a man who collected other men’s laziness for fun, and when, in the afternoon, Arif stood on the stage and was told once again to lift his chin so the camera could see his soul, he did it without flinching because some parts of the day had opted for comedy instead of horror and he intended to thank them by participating.

The night before the final laid itself across the city like a blanket a grandmother would approve of—weighty enough to dampen nonsense, light enough to allow breath. Lila closed the shutter on her stall earlier than her enemies would have dared, announced to the alley that tomorrow was for shouting and today was for boiling water and rubbing feet, and accepted the scandalized murmurs as her due. They walked the long way back to the Liris because the longer you take getting to a bed the better it rewards you, and under the footbridge someone had drawn three chalk feathers and then drawn a boat over them, and the boat had a mast that leaned like an ear. Arif looked down at it and, without smiling, felt the mule in his chest stop kicking so hard.

He sat on the deck while the harbor talked to itself, the ribbon under his thumb and the taste of cinnamon and citrus at the back of his tongue the way a good song sits behind your teeth. He let his breath lengthen because he would ask it to do ugly work tomorrow and he wanted to be grateful in advance. He thought about the faces he would not have to look at when the lights hit him, about the hands he would hear more than see, about the discipline of letting your eyes soften past cameras to focus on a cousin’s silhouette that would stand at the very back of the tent where the shadows could do their job. He thought, ferociously and with a simplicity that shocked him into laughter, about eating. He imagined the first crust and the second and how he would not let sweet become his enemy until he was ready to set the knife down himself, and he promised the part of him that knew how to listen to the sea that he would come back to his own deck after and not belong to anyone else’s table.

Sleep took him with both hands and put him down in a place he recognized, and, just before the floor under him turned into the first swell of a dream, he felt the raw edge of a ribbon press against his thumb and knew, with an absolute that required no witness, that even if the rest of the memory refused him, that one sound, tear and cheer braided together, would not leave. When he woke, it was with that sound still in his mouth and the light on the ceiling doing its best to be gentle, and outside, the harbor cleared its throat as if it had something important to say and wanted to make sure he heard it. He reached for the letter before he reached for his cigarettes, folded it back along the crease he had almost broken, and put it into his pocket like a quiet flag. Then he went up into the morning to find Lila hunched over her pot like a soldier over a map, ready to tell him where to place his feet and how to keep them there when the world tried to move him.

The morning decided to be noisy in a clean way, a kind of bustle that made the harbor’s complaints sound like encouragement, and for once Arif let the racket enter him without sorting it into categories he could fix or ignore. Lila had mapped the day on a scrap of cardboard with arrows and insults, and she moved between her pots with the precision of someone who had invented muscle memory out of stubbornness. The lemon peels sat like curled tongues on the board, the ginger wore its dirt like jewelry, and the palm sugar broke under her spoon with a sound that made the alley pause because it resembled success. Arif took the crate of bottles and rinsed them with a fastidiousness that would have made a pharmacist proud, then stood a moment with his hands in the sink because the water was the exact temperature of a shouted blessing and he had discovered he could collect himself better when his knuckles were submerged. He caught his reflection in the steel and gave it a nod that wasn’t bravado and wasn’t apology, then set about arranging the labels Lila had written in her hurried square hand, each one like a piece of her personality stuck to glass.

Satria arrived before his shadow like a man who had remembered to be early but hadn’t remembered what to do with the time, and he hovered at the edge of the stall wringing his radio as if it were laundry. He had a list and the list was annoyed with him, and he delivered his reminders to the air more than to the people who needed to receive them because he had learned that speaking toward Lila directly this week resulted in bruises to his pride. Security would sweep vendor lanes at ten; the sponsor wanted an insert piece at eleven where contestants pretended to choose their favorite pies; the press wanted a walk-through shot at noon where Gerry would say “community” five times. Lila handed him a cup of warm syrup-water before he had finished the third item and watched him drink like a mother with an opinion about posture, and when he smacked his lips in surprise at the absence of bitterness she allowed herself a small smirk and called it breakfast so he couldn’t argue that she had fed him.

By midmorning the fairground had put on its festival clothes with conviction. Banners that yesterday had looked like laundry now pretended to be flags, and the Mariana Tent swelled with a pride that had very little to do with fabric and a lot to do with the cables that were finally tensioned correctly. Arif walked the edge of the space the way he walked the Liris’s deck after a storm, checking lines and corners for the sort of wrongness you can’t name until it taps you on the shoulder. He greeted Bu Dewi, who had commandeered a corner of a prep table with the authority of a queen on a small throne, and she thumped his chest with the back of her fingers and told him to stop acting like a man about to pray and act like a man about to chew. He glanced toward the service corridor that had tried to swallow his cousin and felt nothing but a brief, clean anger, a steel wire stretched under his breastbone that hummed only when someone pushed against it.

Dara appeared as if the tent had manufactured her, a pleasure of silk where there had recently only been canvas, and stood with her hands clasped behind her back like a teacher evaluating whether to pass a troublesome class. Bram drifted at her shoulder, which made their pairing look like punctuation in a sentence that intimidated commas. They checked the carts discreetly and then not discreetly, which achieved not only security but also a performance of it that discouraged improvisation. When Gerry came flapping like a pelican with a clip-on mic, Dara allowed him to stand too close for thirty seconds, then pulled him away by his jacket lapel with such elegance he thanked her after and did not know why. Jonas passed the far end of the tent and didn’t pass in, which suited everyone, and the boy with the new toothbrush’s neck looked raw where the ink had been scrubbed, which made Arif feel a dark, petty satisfaction he did not examine closely.

The press rehearsal was chaos with excellent lighting, and Arif said his name and the name of his boat four times for four different cameras and made sure to say his cousin’s name every time so that any story told later without her in it would look shabby. He discovered that if he held the microphone slightly farther from his mouth than anyone suggested, the sound man smiled like a man blessed with mercy, and he made a point of liking the sound man so that he could like the whole process more. When a woman in a blazer asked him what pie meant to him and refused to accept “an opportunity to eat politely in public” as an answer, he spoke about crust and labor and the way a country’s arguments become food that refuses to taste like an argument, and she blinked as if the response had contained a small philosophy she would have to edit around. Lila, just off camera, rolled her eyes and drew a small boat on the corner of her clipboard, and when he glanced at her scribble he nearly laughed into the mic and had to pretend he was coughing instead.

Backstage felt like the inside of a chest about to inhale, and the contestants who had done this before radiated the calm of people who have eaten too much and learned not to die. The stout woman with the headscarf who had taken second last year—you couldn’t think of her as anything but Kak Ayu once you had heard her scold a nephew through a mouthful of pastry—stood beside him and tested the seat of the stool as if preparing to argue with it, and she handed him a rubber band with a solemnity reserved for sacred rites. He looked at it with question written across his face and she wrapped it around his wrist herself, not tight, and told him that when the sugar began to talk nonsense he should snap it once to remind his blood of salt. He nodded and thanked her like a man just given a charm by a witch in a market, and when she winked with half a lid and told him not to embarrass her by fainting, he promised to embarrass her in other ways instead.

They called the finalists to the curtains because men with clipboards always appear in multiples, and Satria executed his one indispensable function: he made eye contact with Arif and used his eyebrows to ask a question about readiness that contained apology, gratitude, and panic. Arif nodded in a way that gave him an excuse to walk away to harass someone else. The noise in the tent thickened, laughter piling on laughter until the roof had something heavier than fabric to hold up, and the front rows filled with aunties who would judge everything and still cheer, teenagers who filmed each other’s faces instead of the stage, and a smattering of men who liked to explain to their dates what eating is. Somewhere in the middle was a seat saved by someone important who had texted that they were on their way, and Arif decided he would pretend no such person existed because he had learned that invisible people take up the most room.

He stood, just inside the curtain’s shadow, and watched the first wave of introduction wash over the tent. The emcee had the voice of a man who could make a riot feel like a raffle and he said Arif’s name with that rolling grandeur that makes syllables stick together, and the crowd made the right noise at the right time, which is the kind of mercy performers spend lifetimes craving. He stepped out into the light and let the heat strike him like an oath, and he chose his pace the way you choose a path across a moving deck, slow enough to be stubborn, quick enough to be polite. He did not look for Lila because he had promised her and himself not to, and instead he looked at the top edge of the tent where the canvas turned into sky, and the line held like a sentence he could finish. When the emcee handed him a ribboned garland to wear later and the ribbon’s end brushed his hand, a small electric bolt ran up his thumb to his jaw, and he put the sensation in his pocket beside the actual strip of blue and the letter, folded almost to death.

The first round was savory, as if the tournament wished to prove that it had learned restraint since last year’s festival of sugar. Beef rendang wrapped in flaky pastry that threw crumbs like confetti at every attempt to be dignified, a jackfruit curry pie that smelled like someone’s cousin telling a story loudly and well, and a mushroom thing that declared politely it would not be anyone’s favorite and therefore would last long enough to be remembered. Arif took the stool and planted his feet as if he intended to grow roots through the plywood and into the ground, and he accepted the first plate with a small bow to the auntie who handed it to him because he had decided all hands that fed him would be acknowledged. The water pitchers were arranged exactly as Bu Dewi had insisted, and he took a breath in the space between first bite and second that had been paced his whole body for him, and he began.

It was not a storm at first. It was a river that understood where it was going and did not panic about the bends. The rendang brought heat that sat like an educated older relative on his shoulder and advised him not to rush, and he nodded internally and obeyed, letting the flakes do their work, letting warm water carry corners where they needed to go. He let his jaw be a machine he did not manage, only monitored, and when the emcee shouted something he didn’t catch, the crowd’s answer washed over him and left nothing behind but a thin residue of approval that did not distract. He had thought he would need to think of fishing to survive the stage, but it turned out that all he needed to think about was bite, swallow, breathe, and the way his tongue could be told to enjoy salt without betraying him to thirst.

He glanced once, allowed himself that, to the back corner where the tent met the darker air, and saw the angle of Lila’s jaw and the quirk at the corner of her mouth she thought made her look stern and actually made her look like home. She was not counting animals this time; she was counting backward by lemon peels, which he recognized because he had watched her do it when she thought twice at once. When his eyes flicked front again, they caught Kak Ayu’s grin, and the older woman exaggerated a breath and a swallow for him as if they were teammates in a game nobody else understood, and he obeyed her because she was right. The buzzer for the first round went off with a triumphal whine that had ambitions, and he put his hands in his lap a second before it sounded, just to practice letting go before something wrenched letting go out of him.

Between rounds Gerry swanned onstage with a silver tray to do a sponsor gag and managed not to drop anything, which caused the audience to clap too hard because there is always a certain relief in the avoidance of a small disaster. Dara offered a polite wave with fingers barely separated enough to constitute a gesture, and Jonas hovered, applauding with the air of a man who would like to be mistaken for someone better while hoping no one asks for specifics. Satria looked like someone had told him he could go home early if no speakers caught fire, and he took his new privilege seriously. Arif took the opportunity to stretch his hands, flex his throat with warm water, and let his gaze pass over the tent like a searchlight looking for nothing, because sometimes the looking soothes without needing to find.

The second round brought fruit pies the tent had argued about for weeks in kitchens and group chats. There was apple, because it soothed the anxieties of judges who had learned their English from television, but the apples had been convinced to grow in Indonesian pastry, which made them less pious and more fun. There was soursop, which tried to be shy and failed in a charming way, and a pineapple that bit back just enough to flirt. The durian tart did not appear yet because Bu Dewi had declared it a finale and nobody with any sense argued with her. Arif let the sweetness come and did not let it stay, ushering each mouthful along with a city bus conductor’s efficiency, a hand hovering, a nod, an insistence. He felt, once or twice, the sugar whispering an invitation to a dream, and he took the rubber band and let it kiss his wrist with that clean snap that felt like a boyhood game, and the whisper went away to bother someone else.

Halfway through the pineapple, with his mouth in that exact balance between grateful and polite, the garland’s loose ribbon end brushed his thumb again, and for a second the tent shifted and he was standing in the exact light he had stood in last year. The noise bent like sugar glass, and he saw himself laughing with a garland crooked, the blue edge under his thumb, Lila’s face shining in a way he had not allowed himself to think about because it felt like stealing from a version of himself he could not name. He felt the heat of a hand on the back of his neck that could only have been Pak Kacek’s, steady and vulgar and loving, pushing him back toward the stage when he had staggered off it too quickly. The sensation lasted the length of a swallow and then collapsed, but it left behind a map he did not have to hold to follow.

He did not let the map make him faster. He did not let it make him sentimental. He used it like a skipper uses the feel of a particular crosscurrent under his hull, a fraction of a correction here that makes the turn more elegant an hour hence. When the emcee, hungry for drama, asked him to show the crowd how a champion enjoys a pie, he put his mouth on a slice of apple and chewed slow enough for the first row to laugh at their own nervousness, then broke the pace so hard that the laughter turned into a cheer because people love to be wrong in the correct direction. He could feel his body beginning to treat sugar like a friend who had overstayed, and he fed it warm water and a thought about salt and carried it into the next round with firm courtesy.

Savory returned to rescue the tent from itself. The organizers called it Tradition and then giggled at their own audacity because nothing that uses shredded chicken and coconut so sincerely is truly traditional in a city that changes recipes whenever a wind blows from another island. The pies had names that made the emcee pronounce vowels with reverence and for once his choice was correct, and the smell of lemongrass under butter made more than one auntie elbow the person next to her and declare that this, at least, tasted the way memory claims. Arif took the chicken lemongrass, smiled at the fact that his hands did not shake, and let the bird and the grass tell his jaw where to go.

He felt the wobble at the edge of his knees three bites later the way you feel a floor flex on a ferry and know someone loaded a truck wrong, and he set the pie down for exactly two counts like a man refuses to be rushed and then picked it up again without drama. Kak Ayu snorted with approval and increased her own pace because she had been waiting for him to remember that grace is a show you give the audience to convince them not to worry about you, and as he matched her, a chant began in the back of the tent that had nothing to do with names and everything to do with mouth sounds people make when their bodies want permission to shout. He felt the tent open like a lung, and he breathed with it, and it gave some of its air back to him as if it had made it in the first place just so that he could take it.

The finale arrived like a relative you had been dreading and were delighted to see anyway. Bu Dewi’s durian tart came borne by two aunties who knew not to tilt the plate because dignity is not a liquid, and even the men who claim to hate the fruit looked interested because they admired bravado. The emcee did not try a joke because he had learned, if not humility, then at least when to fear it, and he stood back with his microphone like a man giving space to an avalanche. The smell walked down the first row and slapped every nose and was slapped back with adoration, and Arif felt something similar to love and decided he would tell nobody that because it would ruin three people’s afternoons.

He took his slice and let the fat and the sugar and the echo of something alchemical sit on his tongue just long enough to remind his brain what to call it, then pushed it along politely with warm water and a strict instruction to his throat not to be clever. The second bite tried to announce itself as the one that would make him slow dramatically in a way that cameras could interpret as vulnerability, and he pushed past it with the moral superiority of a man who has been lectured by a cousin wearing lipstick. He tasted a note in the custard that was not Bu Dewi’s and realized she had been merciful and added a whisper of citrus to calm the extravagant animal, and he sent her gratitude with a side-eye and a nod and she received it with a snort and a raised spoon like a salutation.

He heard the cheer begin in the back again, the one with no name, the one that belonged to mouths and lungs and the question of whether any of us are ever doing anything except proving we can use the bodies we are in, and under it he heard the thready sound of ribbon scraping thumb, not from fabric but from memory, and he let himself press into it as he took the next mouthful. He did not speed up. He did not slow down. He reached the end of his plate before he had planned to by three swallows and let the space sit empty because he would not be ruled by the space any more than by the plate, and he took water into himself like a promise instead of a hedge against fear.

It became evident, in that not-dramatic way that good narratives become evident, that the contest was between him and Kak Ayu again, and the cameras thirsted like bad friends for a frame they could put on thumbnails, and Arif and the woman chose to give them something better. They widened their jaws with a shared joke and then narrowed their eyes as if demanding the pies try harder, and they moved hunger out of theater and into craft. When the emcee went too close to Kak Ayu with his microphone, she did not swat him; she fed him a crumb with such authority the front row roared, and when the camera dipped too close to Arif’s face he gave it the expression he had saved, the one that said this is work, not spectacle, but lucky you, you get to watch.

The buzzer that ended the round did not sound like anything but a buzzer; it did not carry glory in its mouth, and Arif was grateful for that because he did not want glory to sound like a machine. He set his hands in his lap again, the habit now a rhythm rather than a rehearsal, and he let himself turn his head. The back of the tent had gone into that slow-motion quiet that happens when bodies forget to coordinate, and Lila’s chin was up and her eyes were shining in a way that no longer hurt him to see because he had earned the right to be looked at like that again. He exhaled and let his shoulders drop and realized they had been up around his ears, and then he stood because the emcee had said something like “count” and numbers had their way with tables and people’s breath.

The tally took long enough for three stupid things to have happened and none did, which felt like a gift. Someone tried to start a wave and gave up. A small boy asked his mother if champions get to choose their own bedtimes and was told yes by a woman who knew how to keep men happy. Gerry whispered at Dara and got a no with such elegance he found himself smiling as if the refusal had been dessert, and Satria stared at a cable tie like it had offended his religion. Bram leaned near a support column with his hands in his pockets and the ghost of a smile and met Arif’s gaze and tipped his head half a degree in the universal language of men who are ready to do something quietly violent if anyone asks them to, and Arif tipped his head back the exact measure that says Not today, thank you.

When the emcee stretched the last syllable of Arif’s name as if trying to make it into a bridge and then screamed it as if he were birthing it himself, the tent breathed and the roof held and the cheering landed on Arif’s shoulders like birds who had chosen him. He did not pretend to be surprised because the kind of false humility that impresses strangers would have hurt his friends; he let delight register because he wanted to see it on Lila’s face like sunrise. He went forward without bounding, because bounding belongs to men who think the world owes them the kind of romance that makes ankles break, and he accepted the ribboned garland—a new one, ridiculous and perfect—and the trophy shaped like a pie and as heavy as an insult. He felt the blue again under his thumb and this time when it tore, because it would always tear, because the edge was wrong for the knot, he tore it deliberately and offered the torn end to Kak Ayu like a shared dessert, and she snatched it with a grin and bit it for the camera and the photo was the kind of photo people will put above their televisions when they need to remember that theater is a trustworthy liar.

He laughed. It was the same laugh as the one on the board and it was not, because last year’s laugh had been full of surprise and sugar and a young man’s invincibility, and this year’s carried the weight of a freezer and a canal and a boy with a toothbrush and a woman in a tamarind dress telling him to choose his fights. It tasted like cinnamon and citrus and salt because Lila had added salt to everything that week, including Arif’s illusions, and he laughed until he had to put the trophy down because he is not a man who loves props. He leaned into Kak Ayu’s side as if she were a cousin and said something about rice that made only their row laugh, and then he straightened and did the one indulgence he had promised himself he would allow if the crowd permitted it. He faced the back of the tent like it was his real stage and bowed his head for half a beat, and when he lifted it Lila was wiping her cheek with the heel of her hand with a ferocity that insisted the tear was a mistake, and he believed her because it made her happy to be believed.

The afterpieces were the same kind of nonsense they are everywhere, no matter the country. Photographs he would not want to look at later and would be forced to, microphones thrust like a plant you don’t remember planting that needs watering right now, offers to take his jacket off and put another one on because someone needed a story about transformation. He did his duty and smiled at two children who had been bribed with balloons to care about pastry, and he held up a slice of something for a camera and did not put it in his mouth, and he stood for a group of bakers who wanted a picture for their wall and meant it when he told them he would come and eat their cakes and give them honest opinions. He did not allow Gerry to drape the Blue Heron jacket over his shoulders, and when the man persisted and flirted with the edge of flustered, Dara rescued them both by performing the kind of small social surgery that leaves nobody bleeding and everyone grateful.

He slipped offstage not like a thief but like a man finished with a job, and the backstage corridor made a sound like a kettle cooling because the energy had to go somewhere and decided to evaporate. Lila met him halfway to the water coolers and slipped her fingers into his and squeezed once so hard his bones chimed, and then she let go and punched him in the shoulder because this felt safer under a tent full of people who love to talk. He bent his head and she stood on her toes and he kissed her forehead because nobody could make that vulgar and because some gestures needed to be taught to anyone watching, and then they stood a second with their foreheads almost touching and let the noise go over them like the after-blow of a wave that had decided not to capsize a small boat after all.

“Eat,” she said, and shoved a banana fritter at his mouth as if it were medicine, because in her hands it was, and he obeyed and felt the grease chase the sugar out and go sit in his stomach like a caretaker on a night shift. “Drink. Sit. Don’t say yes to anything that asks for your soul. Only give them the parts you can regrow.”

“Which parts are those?” he asked, and she pretended to check his elbows like a butcher being practical.

“The laugh,” she decided. “Keep lending that out. And the way you breathe when you decide not to be afraid. That one you can give to anyone who asks nicely. Keep the ribbon. Keep the way you look at boats.”

Back by the service carts Bram affected the disinterest of a man who has used a whole day’s quota of interest and finds he has an emergency reserve anyway, and he inclined his head at the trophy, then at Arif’s face, in that order because he had opinions about sequence. There was a flash of something like pride in him that he did not allow to take up the whole room, and then he moved as if he were about to go chase a different problem with a net, and Arif stopped him with a hand on his sleeve because there were too many things in him that might become foolish if not given to someone safe. He thanked him with words that were not elaborate and that made Bram glance down once like he had heard a bird that is rare in the city, and then Bram told him, with a casualness that was a lie for his benefit, that the man with the ring had been quiet since noon, which in their world meant a lawyer had told him to hibernate.

Outside the tent the late afternoon had chosen drama after all and stacked clouds in layers like a cake for a wedding that would end in a fight, and there was wind on the water that smelled like change and the burnt electricity of machines who are bored of themselves. The crowd spilled into the midway in a version of happiness that did not involve anyone shouting at anyone else, and vendors were declaring that their stock had been underestimated and that their hands were tired and that their children would eat and the television would be loud. Arif found himself imagining the harbor at night when he was a boy, and how he had lain on his back and told Lila names of foreign boats like an aunt telling gossip, and he felt as stupidly lucky as a man who has jumped a wave and landed with both ankles willing.

The Blue Heron after-party sat on the city’s tongue like a bet it intended to win, and there was work left to do there that had nothing to do with pastry. Dara had promised to build a drink that tasted like money without making anybody a liar, and she had promised to teach men the limits of feathers, and Lila had promised to make syrup that made your mouth remember kindness first and none of them were in the habit of breaking promises made under tent lights. Arif thought of the freezer and the canal and the boy and the toothbrush and the ugly shoes that might yet become rice and a duck, and he decided he would go to a club and stand in a corner and not drink anything with a name because he would rather watch a woman who could fold a room into a better shape do her work.

At the Liris, Pak Kacek had tied the line in a way that said he was showing off for anyone who might be watching, which is to say, the boat. He saw them approach with their ridiculous trophy and their smaller ridiculous garland and made a face like he disapproved of celebrations that required dusting, then kissed the trophy, very quickly, when he thought nobody would see. He told a story about a sailor who won a pig at a fair by guessing its weight and then had to carry it home because the pig refused to be led, and he told it in such a way that the moral could have been anything from “choose your prizes with wisdom” to “tie better knots” and he left them to decide which because good educators are lazy and proud. Lila held up the ribbon strip and he took it without asking for explanation and made of it a loop he could tie to a place near the companionway where good-luck garbage lives on boats, and he put a knot in it that would only come undone if insulted.

They ate, modestly, because their bodies had had enough indignity for one day, and they sat with their feet up in a way that would have made their grandmothers scold and their grandfathers grin, and they made a plan that was not a plan so much as a list of where to stand and who to deflect and what to avoid being photographed doing. They agreed not to wake Bu Dewi because she would wake herself when her brain decided to swing its lantern around the room of her ideas, and they agreed to take the long road to the club because the short road had too many men who loved putting their hands on other people’s backs to steer them.

At Blue Heron the door had learned to smile, which is to say the doorman had had a conversation with humility, and the heron on the wall lifted its metal head not at all because art has nothing to say to days like these. Inside, the room had been altered in small ways that would only be noticed by people who make and break rooms for a living. The bar’s back shelf held Lila’s bottle in pride of place, not by label because she didn’t have one, but by aura, and Dara stood with one hip against the wood like a general in peacetime. The men with rings and jackets looked like men who had been shown a boundary and decided to live, for now, on the safe side of it, and Gerry was overacting his own good behavior so hard it became charming despite itself.

There were toasts. There are always toasts. Dara raised her glass not high, because you don’t need God to watch you for truth, and spoke about work and mouths and how it is rude to build a city with your waist and your back and then pretend the mouths are decoration. She did not say Jonas’s name and did not look at him and the omission made him smaller than any insult could have achieved. Bram said nothing and the nothing was generous. Lila accepted three compliments and corrected one recipe and refused to take money for the first batch of syrup because she had decided the proper payment would be in favors owed and a small plaque near the bathroom that said “Don’t be stupid” in a nice font. Arif, who had no gift for clubs, stood with his back to a column and watched men pretend their hearts had never been dangerous.

He saw him then, not because the man had announced himself but because the room tilted half a degree and his eyes, newly taught to read that particular tilt, followed without his consent. Not Jonas, not the ring, not the boy, but the person their feathers dreamed of being attached to, the one who had hired impatience as a personality. He was not tall or short and his suit did not have a seam out of place and his shoes had a softness to their shine that indicated calfskin and a deliberate decision to never cross a road without a car waiting for him. He had a face that would not survive humor and eyebrows that had practiced disapproval in the mirror until it looked natural. He did not look at Arif, because men like him do not look at sailors until sailors have made a mess, and for a moment Arif felt the old compressor of his chest try to turn on and he unplugged it because there was nothing that needed pressure right now.

Dara approached the man as if they were opposite teams instructed to act like cousins at a funeral. She smiled with the precise number of teeth that make rich men behave, and she said something inaudible and the man did that quick little shake of the head men do when they are refusing something they consider beneath them, which made Bram’s mouth quirk in a way that meant somebody had just made a list longer. The three of them stood in a triangle that looked like a math problem and then the triangle solved itself with a shrug and a nod and a later, and the man drifted away like a large fish that has decided the net looks too expensive to be worth chewing.

Lila slid beside Arif and slid a glass into his hand and told him to drink because it would be bad manners to refuse to honor the part of the day that didn’t require a napkin. He sipped and felt her syrup behave the way it had promised it would—sharp where sophistication tends to lie, sweet where nostalgia pretends to be honest, bitter only in memory. She leaned into his side like she had chosen to and not because her ankles had lost interest in standing, and they watched Dara make the room do as it was told with posture and a smile and a casual sentence about a river that made three men look at their shoes. They did not speak for a while, because mouths sometimes improve a scene by closing.

When they left, the club let them, which is not a kindness you can count on. The night outside was honest and held no adjectives beyond wet and electric, and the walk back felt like a procession of two that nobody else needed to witness. The garland had lost two pastry leaves and they ate them with indecent pleasure because stealing from symbols makes them feel useful. The harbor sang the song it always sings when it is ready to be a mirror, and the Liris lifted them as if to prove a point to the other boats watching. Lila went below with a declaration about washing her face until it remembered mercy, and Arif stood at the rail with his fingers on the ribbon loop and his thumb worrying the little raw edge he had made on purpose, and he allowed himself to close his eyes and see two versions of himself stacked like transparencies and feel less anger at the space between them than he would have thought he was allowed.

He slept a smaller sleep that did not feel cheated, and he woke before the alarm he did not set and the day after the day felt like a piece of bread someone had warmed just for him. He found Lila in the galley pouring tea as if pouring tea were an offensive art, and she handed him a cup without looking up and told him she had dreamt of feathers turning into noodles and he told her that meant the day would be good because noodles fill people in a way feathers don’t. He checked the letter out of habit and put it away faster than he had yesterday because it was now a souvenir and not a guide, and he stood on deck with his hands braced and smelled a morning that had decided to be human.

There would be interviews to be bothered by, and a return to Bu Dewi’s to be fed whether he agreed or not, and a visit from a boy who might bring a duck if the world had behaved, and a network of men with rings and wrists who had reconsidered their feathers. There would be a new job for Lila to refuse three times before deciding to accept on her own terms, and a set of security cameras to reteach to be honest, and a boss of some boys to be shown the place where rivers end as a lesson in humility. There would be, under all of it, the fact that his thumb remembered what ribbons feel like and his mouth remembered where to put its breath and his heart remembered how to let bells ring without thinking they were alarms. He took a sip of tea and let it scald the roof of his mouth a little because it felt correct, and then he turned to tell Lila a stupid joke he had been saving, and the boat leaned, attentive, to hear it.
